column1: I tried to embrace this book--I really did. It was tempting to want to have at last found a piece of academic writing that deftly encapsulates and explains this clash of titans: jihad and globalism. Barber's main title is
column2: however
column3: more tantalizing than explanatory. This book demonstrates the dangers of allegiance to dichotomies; there are other forces at work in society that grapple with the headline-stealing titans.  This is an important book at least insofar as it captures a growing sentiment among academics interested in the socio-economic forces that compel current events. It is not
column4: therefore
column5: an easy read for the layman (particularly the last part of the book) which is ironic given his call to grassroots citizen action.   Barber asserts--really insists with an uncomfortable brand of academic arrogance--in almost narrowly political overtones that the world is immersed in a battle of opposing ideologies: the corporate
column6: amoral and homogenized one that really is without ideology and the local
column7: or tribal
column8: and rigidly moral and fragmented one that is part ideology
column9: part myth-making.  Unfortunately
column10: in his earnestness to construct and defend his convenient dichotomy
column11: he conforms exceptions to his rule. The jihadists--whether ethnic hatemongers or terrorists--have for Barber retained some residue of moral dignity while the globalist--whether gullible
column12: materialistic and indifferent consumers or manipulative
column13: multinational executives--have altogether lost their moral compass.  His solution (which he fails to outline
column14: thus making his work more of a polemic and manifesto rather than manual for change) is an activist citizenry fully appreciative of their need and ability to shore up the civil sector of modern societies. Here again Barber is remiss
column15: revealing that writing from one's desk rather than the field has its limitations. He fails to acknowledge
column16: for example
column17: the extent to which the lack of a civic tradition in such nations as Russia and China impedes social progress of the sort he pines for. And the following further indicates his lack of awareness of Chinese cultural resiliency: "What is striking is that even here where a native culture might be thought to have its greatest chances against the children of the Western Enlightenment
column18: McWorld seems irresistible."(190)  Aside from this concern
column19: and his lack of concrete solutions and elusive
column20: often inaccessible writing style
column21: Barber tends to exaggerate the extent to which corporate influence is mitigated by both government and civic organizations
column22: especially in the Western democracies. He is undeservedly far too pessimistic in this regard and fails to note the many ways in which a bygone American lacked a collective sense of civic duty. Moreover
column23: his analysis is flawed
column24: as I believe you will also discover
column25: by his apparent aspirations to global citizenship. Nor

column1: I've used the Schick Quattro for about 3 years now and have been happy with it.  I thought I would try out this powered M3 razor to see what all the hype was about.  Many of my friends said they got the best shave ever using it: No razor burn
column2: bumps
column3: or nicks etc.  However
column4: the M3 gave me more razor burn and nicks than any razor I've ever used! Could it have been that I wasn't used to the Mach 3 blades after using a Quattro for years?  To rule out blade differences
column5: I subsequently tried the Power Quattro and obtained similar
column6: albeit less drastic
column7: negative results.    In particular
column8: both the M3 and Power Quattro really did a number on my neck area.  I even had people comment on how abused my neck looked after shaving with these two razors.  Both Gillette and Schick assert that vibrations diminish irritation and lead to a superior shave.  In my case
column9: I believe that vibrations actually lead to more irritation!  My personal experience with these razors
column10: and my cynical nature
column11: lead me to believe that vibrating razors are just another ploy by the shaving industry to get people to buy more product (i.e.
column12: aftershave creams and lotions to cover up the mess that such razors create).    My advice is to avoid these powered hybrids alltogether and stick with a regular Quattro or Mach 3 razor.

column1: I bristle at the suggestion that perhaps Roosevelt knew of the attack but did nothing to stop it
column2: as if a repulsed sneak attack would not have convinced America to go to war.  The conspiracy theory holds that Roosevelt had the carriers shipped out of Pearl
column3: leaving the obsolete battleships to be destroyed in the attack.  The one glaring problem with this theory (actually there are several problems
column4: but I consider this the most compelling) can be summarized in a single word: oil.  A HUGE amount of oil was stored at Pearl
column5: such a huge amount in fact that the carriers and subs would have been out of action probably for an entire year
column6: if the oil had been destroyed.  The value of that oil was tremendous
column7: and Roosevelt would have been absolutely demented to risk it.  It was pure luck that the Japanese did not target it (they actually planned to hit it on the aborted third run).  Additionally
column8: Roosevelt was a former Navy Secretary who referred to the Army as "them" and the Navy as "us".  It is way beyond belief that he would have sacrificed the battleships and their crews
column9: much less the oil.  It's always sooooo simple to monday morning quarterback
column10: a lesson to keep in mind today regarding Iraqi WMD

column1: Even a supporter of Bush will see no purpose for it. Non-supporters will see it for what it is - pure propaganda.  Just one of so many books that represent a waste of good trees.

A friend of mine works for an petrochemical exploration company.  They specialize in determining potential locations of oil deposits by drilling cores into layers of sedimentary deposits and looking at the evolutionary sequences of micro-fossils which were accumulated millions of years ago on ancient sea-floors. Oil (and coal) deposits formed when decaying plant matter became buried under sediments and underwent subsequent chemical alteration.  The plant material requires millions of years to be converted into oil or coal. (They're called fossil fuel for a reason
column2: you know.)  When you analyze a drill core sample
column3: and if you find particular micro-fossils of species that only lived during a certain geological age that corresponds to the age when oil deposits formed
column4: then you might be in an area where oil can be found.  Her company gets contacts from huge oil companies to help them make multi-billion dollar decisions on where to drill for oil based partly on the information obtained by looking at micro-fossils.  Oil companies have been doing this for decades. Don't believe me.  Find out for yourself.  Search the internet for websites about oil exploration micropaleontology.  Next time you fill your tank
column5: consider the role evolution played in both the creation and the discovery of the gas you're pumping into your car.  I own stock in the company my friend works for and have made some nice returns on it.  I also have a relative who works for a medical research institute that uses DNA analysis to find out how viruses and genetic defects cause disease.  He's working on therapies for several types of cancer.  They use genetic mutations and evolutionary histories of diseases to understand how cells
column6: viruses and diseases operate.  They've already had success with some drugs and I've made money off of a drug company's stock as a result.  The science is way over my head.  However
column7: based on the logic of this book
column8: you have to conclude that genetic mutations can't be studied with any certainty because it seems they can occur only if and when God wants them to.  I don't know how I'll be able to break it to him but I guess someone will have to tell him that his research is simply a waste of time.  I know that seems at odds with the fact I've made money off the stock market . . . but Phillip Johnson wants me to have an open mind after all
column9: and
column10: let's face it
column11: he's so much smarter than these people.  I can't imagine how insulting it must be to intelligent
column12: dedicated
column13: highly educated
column14: hard working
column15: honest
column16: professional people like these
column17: who use the principles of evolution in their day to day work
column18: in billion dollar industries
column19: for them to hear people say that evolution didn't happen or that it is just an ideology. (I should sell the stock in these companies soon
column20: before they crash when word gets out that evolution is a myth.)  Folks
column21: there is a tremendous amount of information supporting evolution. In all honesty
column22: it is downright silly to contend at this point that living things have not evolved over the eons.  It is simply a fact of life.  It is not a religious belief or an opinion.  I urge you to truly inform yourselves about evolution from sources other than creationists or  IDers or whatever they call themselves.  Look at the depth and detail of information supporting evolution.  There are many websites about it. Check them out.  Look at some professional research journals on subjects related to biology
column23: geology
column24: palenotology
column25: etc.  Ask yourself
column26: "Can this tremendous amount of detailed information accumulated by researchers for hundreds of years really be fake or incorrect?"  "Are all the thousands of highly intelligent
column27: highly educated people around the world who are currently conducting research on evolution
column28: as well as those using it in their daily work
column29: all wrong?"  "Would scientists at the most prestigious universities in the world really deliberately lie about this?"  "Why would they risk being caught in a lie and ruin their professional careers?"  Please
column30: be realistic about science.  And
column31: by the way
column32: you can be Christian and fully accept evolution.  I do.  So do the friend and relative I mentioned above.  Of course
column33: I guess we're just closed-minded.

column1: inconsequential jargon  This pseudo-philosophical work is long
column2: insubstantial and boring. The author tries to hide his sterility by avoiding the very basic and fundamental social and human problem
column3: the problem of universal injustice. One wonders why on earth someone should attempt such a work! The title itself betrays the author's philosophical incompetence: "A Theory of Justice." Hasn't he read Plato? Doesn't he realize that justice is not a theory
column4: but in fact practice? What on earth is a theory of justice
column5: which cannot be put to practice? Right at the beginning of his book Rawls insists on a "veil of ignorance" in order to have fairness to start with.; that is plunging into a book
column6: which has nothing give
column7: which can do nothing to change the world we live in. We are not blind. We know too well that there can be no justice in a society whose members are not blind and deaf
column8: and know too well that there are differences separating individuals. How can anyone insist on capitalism
column9: annual growth and availability of goods for all when the world is limited and the earth with its limited natural resources cannot sustain unchecked human growth? And what is more
column10: he can never define what good are
column11: which must be available to everyone. Is raw materialism justice? Are we chickens in a coop
column12: absolutely predictable? The author should have examined the history of philosophy a little more carefully
column13: which is nothing other than a series of failures in putting the cart before the horse
column14: that is theory before practice.  Haven't we learned the lesson from communism and its disastrous results? Marxism too was an elaborate theory
column15: but in reality turned out to be a gross injustice to all. Is the unquestioned democracy the final truth? Before embarking on another long
column16: empty and pretentious "theory" without foundation a thinker should make him/herself well acquainted with human nature. It is too bad that this jargon is often taught at colleges and universities
column17: forcing nave students read this book
column18: discuss it
column19: and even worse
column20: write term-papers on it. For those who wish to have a clear-cut understanding of social problems and a sound theory of justice I recommend Plato's Republic.  Academic jargon is not philosophy.

column1: The authors have so much enthusiasm for their topic that I truly wanted to write a positive review
column2: but unfortunately their enthusiasm is the only redeeming quality of the book. True
column3: you can learn some things about searching for gold with a metal detector. And although the authors disclaim any purpose to sell their products
column4: they refer to them exclusively on the grounds that they are most familiar with them. Well
column5: OK
column6: but it still has an uncomfortable feel to it. And I felt I was unable to translate many of their instructions to generic terms (for use with any brand metal detector).  Early on you are advised that terms are defined in the glossary. But they should also be defined in the text so that one does not have to continually stop reading and refer to the glossary. This is basic to didactic writing. For example
column7: the term "placer" is used many times before it is defined. Ground balancing (canceling) is treated the same way.   There are several passages that are repeated verbatim in different chapters and you are left wondering if you have somehow read the current chapter already! It appears that the editor of the book was in a great rush
column8: or extremely inexperienced. I could not find any reference to RAM publications on the web. The editor was found
column9: and seems to be mostly associated with the works of Garret and Lagal.  Was it worth the price? I suppose
column10: as I at least felt the excitement of hunting for gold. But it would be better titled as a companion to one of the Garret manufactured metal detectors.  I still hope to find a book on using the metal detector as a hobby that is a better-written "how to" book that speaks in generic terms about metal detectors.

column1: I want to take a moment to address the battle system and the license system.  These systems
column2: while well-conceived
column3: have completely ruined the game for me.  For example
column4: the license system is
column5: itself
column6: a very good idea:  It allows the player to craft the character to his liking and tastes.  The problem lies in the execution.   Say
column7: for example you want to learn "Steal." Not only do you have to get the license for it but you also have to purchase it in the game.  This presents problems. In my game
column8: for example
column9: my characters possess a suite of licenses that they cannot use because the shops don't carry that particular item.  The system gives you flexibility but snatches it away by requiring that you not only get the license but to also find the item.   I can't help but to feel hobbled by the license system.  Because these items (which require licenses) come at discrete parts of the game
column10: the developers have cunningly shot up the difficulty.  It doesn't matter that I earned the license for "Shield of Fire" at level 4
column11: I can only get it at level 20+ when its offered in a shop!  The game is very challenging precisely because the mechanics prevent characters from getting better-than-normal equipment after they earned the license. The sly
column12: artificial way the developers of FFXII ramped up the difficulty strips away seems almost arbitrary and unnecessary. The cap of three playable characters (at one time) is the straw that breaks the camel's back.   Lastly
column13: the battle system
column14: in my opinion
column15: isn't fitting for a console RPG.  It feels like I am playing World of Warcraft or City of Heroes. The enemies are always faster than you.  It's nigh impossible to chase them down and they always are able to catch up with you. Fighting with a bow is an exercise in futility: the enemies will catch you because the game freezes you in place during firing.   The R2 button
column16: which allows you to flee
column17: borders between being useless to outright deadly to use. While fleeing
column18: the game prevents you from interacting with objects. So if you flee toward a door
column19: you have to stop
column20: pause
column21: let them hit you
column22: before you can escape.    My mouth gaped open when I saw the reviews for the game online.  This game received astronomical scores
column23: some heralding it as the best Final Fantasy ever.  That shocks me beyond belief.   FFXII would be a better MMORPG and an even sharper two-player RPG.  As a single-player game
column24: with shoddy A.I mechanics
column25: the game plays like a tumbling rock.   Perhaps I am just too old school
column26: but this game tastes too much like lollipops and bubblegum.  Your mileage may vary.

column1: In terms of being of value to the reader
column2: I think the Iraq Report fails for multiple reasons.  To start with
column3: there is the panel's decision to only look forward.  I felt the main value of the 9/11 report was the fact that it documented events leading to the attack on 9/11
column4: and provided me with quite a bit of context which I would otherwise be unaware of.  I presume the panel's decision to not look backwards was based partly in Baker's desires to fulfill his duty to the public as well as maintain his loyalty to the Bush family.  If this is the case
column5: I think he provided a disservice to both.  With this decision
column6: the report focuses solving the problem going forward.  I think this renders the report irrelevant as: 1.  Few of the recommendations are being actively pursued
column7: which makes their inclusion in the report a moot point. 2.  It may be based in my partial naivety of world politics
column8: but it seems that many of the recommendations are not realistic.  For example
column9: the report stresses the necessity of participation from Iran and Syria in order to secure success - yet my understanding of the situation leads me to expect that Iran has no desire to help.  In fact
column10: the report itself expresses the fact that Iran has some interest in keeping our hands tied in Iraq.  Either way
column11: with the exception of a brief discussion of the current state of affairs
column12: the report does little to inform.  It does do a bit to explain how bleak the current situation is
column13: but that is hardly a revelation.  The recommendations themselves don't appear helpful.  And as time goes on
column14: they are quickly becoming irrelevant.  The only positive that seems to have come from this report is that it has sparked some discussion.  The report itself falls short

column1: Ravi Zacharias never adequately addresses the core question of atheism.  How do we know that God exists or does not exist?  Atheism argues that God does not exist.  According to atheists
column2: there is no conclusive evidence for the existence of God
column3: unicorns
column4: or other supernatural entities.  The only remaining argument for the existence of the supernatural is FAITH that unicorns and God exist.    From what I've read about atheism
column5: this philosophical stance does not espouse any particular moral system anymore than the belief in God espouses a specific moral system.  If a person claims that the supernatural (or God) exists
column6: then that person has to choose a moral system such as Christianity
column7: Buddhism
column8: Islam and so forth (and a particular sect within that religion).  If a person claims that the supernatural does not exist (atheism)
column9: then that person must pick or develop a moral system.  Examples of secular (without God) moral systems are as follows: (a) secular humanism; (b) the philosophies of Peter Singer
column10: Bertrand Russell
column11: or John Dewey; (c) the morality of your family or community if these people are secular and (d) so forth.

The first chapter opens with a barrage of statistics to show that CT is not adequately taught.Ex: You will live into your '70's so what do you need to know to be prosperous (as if all knowledge for the entire future needs to be acquired today.) The book is riddled with wrong definitions and erroneous information. The chapter on hypothesis testing is especially egregious in that regard. There are few references later than 1991 (in the 3d edition). Finally

column5: logic
column6: and probability theory

column1: It used to be that Rhino took excellent care and pride in all of its releases.  This no longer seems to be the case.  Easily

column4: which works better as a theatrical release than as a listening experience at home on the victrola.  That initial expanded touring band featuring Bernie Worrell of P-Funk fame adding his signature swimming textures and a post-Bowie pre-King Crimson Adrian Belew on scorching guitar was both a revelation for many in the audience uninitiated into either seventies funk or seventies noisy art-rock and an amazing leap into the unknown for Talking Heads.  The expanded version indeed adds some worthy items to the overall set list
column5: such as "The Big Country" on disc one and "Warning Sign" as well as a seemingly Fela-influenced and irresistibly funky "Born Under Punches" on disc two.  However

column8: which not only MADE that particular version of the song
column9: as a contrast to the tempo increase which followed
column10: but was one of the most enjoyable sections of the entire 1980-1981 record.  The beginning of this intro can be heard on the fade at the end of "The Great Curve" where Byrne announces that it's okay to dance if you want to.  Maddeningly
column11: the producers at Rhino chose to remove this section from album
column12: thereby breaking what is essentially rule number one of reissues.  While it's okay to remove crowd noises or orchestrations added after the fact
column13: NEVER
column14: but NEVER
column15: delete ANY MUSIC that was on the original release.  EVER.  FOR ANY REASON.  Those very familiar with an original release will want everything that was on it initially
column16: even the parts they didn't like.  Not only that

column20: if time was an issue for mastering the second disc

column1: This is a strange book
column2: and I couldn't figure out why until about page 225. Donald starts out even on page one lumping a collection of psychologists into a group
column3: and then stereotyping and belittling them. This went on until about page 50. The problem: many of them actually disagreed with each other about the nature of the mind. It was clear that his attacks were unfair. But why?   Then he grandly claims to have a new
column4: improved theory of consciousness. Here is where the book becomes strangely split. One the one hand
column5: he proposes some structures of the mind that may be novel
column6: but which look somewhat like the work of some of the researchers that he had just belittled. He describes structures of the brain and proposes a function he calls episodic awareness. This is the part of the book that I like. But then he insists on welding this new structure to a hypothesis that I find highly speculative (read wrong). He claims that the human brain is a hybird
column7: partly built by biology and partly built by culture. Nothing in his brain / mind science requires that this odd connection be made. Because of this claim
column8: he takes a number of odd positions
column9: such as that novelists are better psychologists that psychologists are
column10: and that language is a cultural skill rather than an instinct. He makes the whopper of a claim that the associative learning of neural nets is responsible for consciousness.    Finally
column11: past page 200
column12: he comes out of the closet. He is actually a connectivist
column13: one of the tradition that was cut to pieces by Steven Pinker in "How the Mind Works." So the better part of his book is his contribution to mind science
column14: which is not incompatible with evolutionary/modular psychology. However
column15: the book's opening attacks and odd hypothesis of humans as cultural cyborgs comes from his desire to reject the modular theory of the mind for the higher faculties of the human thought. In this book
column16: he tries to allow some of the modular brain organization--and here he may actually be making a contribution to mind science--without relinquishing most of the human mind's unique abilities from the connectivist programme. For more details
column17: see my review on WorldCat.

column1: I bought this book in the expectation that it was going to describe the rational foundations for irrational exuberance.  I was most disappointed to realize that it was just a collection of rather anecdotal comments on a few stories of poor business management (e.g.
column2: Enron
column3: Worldcom).    However
column4: not even the commentary is insightful - it only scratches the surface.  I actually think that the title of this book is highly misleading - it is not about how or why market bubbles are created.  Rather
column5: it is a book that very succinctly describes stories of high-profile companies that have coincidentally had their day during times of market bubbles.  To speculate that
column6: for example
column7: Enron and/or its well-paid executives have been the cause of the 2000-2001 NASDAQ crash is to ignore fundamental human psychology and behavior.  Overall
column8: there is no real need to buy or even read this book.  It's unlikely to enlighten any reader wanting to understand the background to the stock market collapse of the 2000s

column1: This book never came together for me.  Right up to the end I was waiting and waiting for everything to come into focus
column2: but it never did.  I never really saw the point the author was trying to make and thus it was a lot of semi-interesting stuff that happened.  The story is about Jack and Connor Reed
column3: whose parents are both dead.  When the story begins
column4: Connor is 17 and being raised by Jack
column5: a junior member of his father's old law firm in Cleveland.  The book then covers the next 23 years of their lives as they marry and divorce and have kids and so forth.  Connor gets Hodgkin's disease but survives while Jack moves to Chicago to reconcile and marry (then divorce
column6: then possibly remarry) his long-time fiancee Mona.  Jack reluctantly has one son with Mona while Connor knocks up his girlfriend Laine and marries her and then divorces her
column7: then possibly will remarry her.  A lot of the story--not just when Connor gets Hodgkin's--has the characters getting sick.  Connor has a migraine.  Laine cuts her hand.  Mona gets mugged and hurts her wrist.  Jack and Connor get food-poisoned on a trip from Cleveland to Massachusetts.  Later Jack gets food-poisoned with his new girlfriend Kathy.  Even Connor's dog gets sick!  The first few times this is fine
column8: but after a while it's repetitive.  Then of course we have Jack and Mona who break up and get together more than Ross and Rachel on "Friends."  This gave the story a soapy edge I doubt the author intended
column9: although she's worked for the National Enquirer
column10: so maybe that's exactly what she meant to do.  Do people really keep breaking up and getting together anywhere other than TV?  And of course Connor and Laine have the same problem to a lesser extent.  Maybe the author wanted us to believe in the bond of family or love or whatever
column11: but as a good 50% of the population (or more) can tell you
column12: most people who break up do not get back together--then break up
column13: then get together
column14: ad nauseum.  But I think the most annoying part of the book is that because it covers 23 years in 260 pages
column15: it's always leaping around.  At the start of every chapter is that disorienting moment when as the reader you're trying to determine when this is taking place
column16: how much time has passed
column17: and what's changed between chapters.  So really you're spending a good quarter of the time reading wondering what the heck is going on.  Not good.  Writing-wise
column18: I'm never a big fan of present tense.  There also seemed like a few grammatical errors and spelling errors the editor did not catch.  There was also at least one factual error as well.  The 1988 movie with Tom Cruise and Dustin Hoffman is "Rain Man" not "Rainman"--a simple check on IMDB could have caught that.  Such trivial errors may seem unimportant
column19: but it erodes my confidence in the author.  Not to mention it's just plain sloppy.  Overall I breezed through this book and it wasn't completely awful
column20: but there are a lot of better books out there.  Still
column21: this is probably a good lightweight read for the plane or beach.  That is all

(2 stars so far)  I really liked the use of language in creating the voice of the narrator.  It gave me the feeling that I was sitting with an elder aunt or grandmother who was telling the story to me.  (Make it 3 stars
column5: bordering on 4).  So
column6: why the 1 star?  Mainly because I did not like what I interpreted to be a thinly disguised attack on a straw man version of Catholicism and I can't rate it a zero.  I found many of the incidents in the story and especially the commentary of the narrator to be very critical of Catholicism.  I find it unfortunate that
column7: like most critics of Catholicism
column8: Castillo critizes/attacks a straw man version of Catholicism rather than the real thing.  In an interview the author was asked about fact checking in works of fiction (specifically in her book "Massacre of the Dreamers")
column9: Castillo answered:  "No. There isn't any point in it. It's your opinion. It's your reflection
column10: your reaction
column11: your own opinion. When you write a critical -- and this isn't personal essays
column12: these are critical essays -- then you have to prove ever single thing you say."  Maybe that's why she chose to attack a straw man rather than the real thing

column1: This has to be the most boring book I have ever read. Well
column2: I haven't quite finished it yet as it's taking forever to push my way through it. And I'm sure that more boring books exist
column3: I just haven't read them.    I wanted to learn about KKR and LBOs - particularly as a division of KKR recently bought one of the vendors supplying my own employer. I was hoping for the big picture of what took place as well as some entertaining anecdotes. But this book consists largely of page after page of uninteresting minutiae of conversations between the various parties involved. There really is no need for such detail and a little bit of editing could have halved the size of the book without losing any essential information. And a bit of theoretical discussion would have been far more valuable than some of the biographical material. It felt a bit like watching someone else's home video. It probably means a lot to the people involved
column4: especially as they'll get the in jokes and quirks of the participants
column5: but it's painfully boring for strangers forced to watch it out of politeness.  I'm sure that much of the conversation is fiction anyway. People don't reliably remember this level of detail of converstaions over a period of years. What are remembered are broad brushstrokes - and this is what the author should have written.  There are occasional moments of entertainment - like Ted Forstmann obsessing about the evils of junk bonds. But most of the characters seem quite flat and uninteresting.   The fact is: I wanted some of this information in this book. As it provided some of this
column6: albeit with a lot of suffering on my part
column7: I'll give it two stars.  Update: Well I did finish this book eventually. My final opinion is much the same

column4: the lyrics are often theologically lame or misleading.  After a few chapters some sympathy for the author was awoken. Zschech is honest about (some of her) mistakes and problems
column5: and it didn't sound too easy to be Darlene Zscech.  Sympathy and biases aside - well maybe not 100 % objetivity will follow... Theologically
column6: Zschech seems to assume a charismatic
column7: evangelical Christianity
column8: influenced by the Word Faith movement. It's a bit vague
column9: since the theology is often only assumed
column10: not described let alone argued. Christians know what they believe
column11: seems to be the assumption
column12: and what is needed is dedication. The question a Christian should ask him- or herself is how much they are willing to worship God. How much are you prepared to sacrifice? From these preconditions (no outlined theology and focus on our service) one easily falls into some form of legalism.  Zschech mixes our work and God's. Our worship seems to be inevitibly blended with God's love. The lyrics in "Shout to the Lord" is no coincidence: "All of my days I want to praise
column13: the wonders of your mighty love". The relationship between God's acts and our worship is even reversed
column14: when Zschech says that God acts as a response to our worship. (Granted
column15: some Bible verses are given to support this view
column16: this is definitely not the general thrust of the Bible.) When we praise God
column17: God acts. This also turnes praise into prayer
column18: in an odd way. Shouldn't praise be a response to what God *has* done (Rev. 4:4; 5:9-10)? If we want God to do something
column19: shouldn't we simply pray?  In this book we can read about a showbusiness spirit
column20: look-at-me spirit
column21: and creating an atmosphere of faith. This kind of hyper-spirituality is not based on the Bible
column22: and tends to ascribe our human faults and sins to spirits (cf. James 1:14). The focus on atmosphere (here and now) may make us somewhat overlook the objectivity of the Gospel and salvation.  What I really miss in this book
column23: is what i percieve as true worship. When believers together sing about and give praise to God for salvation through Jesus' death and resurrection - without any other motives than that. In order to have such worship
column24: Hillsong first would need a sound theology. And in order to have good corporate worship
column25: the "intimacy" of the music and lyrics would have to change since they also tend to make the songs individualistic.  Instead of this book
column26: I would recommend Vaughan Roberts chapter "The Place of Music and Singing in Church"
column27: which can be found in his book "True Worship" or on the internet

column1: 1. The Twelve Steps do not work as a program of recovery from drug or alcohol problems.  The A.A. failure rate ranges from 95% to 100%. Sometimes
column2: the A.A. success rate is actually less than zero
column3: which means that A.A. indoctrination is positively harmful to people
column4: and prevents recovery. Some tests have shown that even receiving no treatment at all for alcoholism is much better than receiving A.A. treatment:  One of the most enthusiastic boosters of Alcoholics Anonymous
column5: Professor George Vaillant of Harvard University
column6: who is also a member of the Board of Trustees of Alcoholics Anonymous World Services
column7: Inc. (AAWS)
column8: showed by his own 8 years of testing of A.A. that A.A. was worse than useless -- that it didn't help the alcoholics any more than no treatment at all
column9: and it had the highest death rate of any treatment program tested -- a death rate that Professor Vaillant himself described as "appalling". While trying to prove that A.A. treatment works
column10: Professor Vaillant actually proved that A.A. kills. After 8 years of A.A. treatment
column11: the score with Dr. Vaillant's first 100 alcoholic patients was: 5 sober
column12: 29 dead
column13: and 66 still drinking.  (Nevertheless
column14: Vaillant is still a Trustee of Alcoholics Anonymous
column15: and he still wants to send all alcoholics to A.A. anyway
column16: to "get an attitude change by confessing their sins to a high-status healer." That is cult religion
column17: not a treatment program for alcoholism.)  The A.A. dropout rate is terrible. Most people who come to A.A. looking for help in quitting drinking are appalled by the narrow-minded atmosphere of fundamentalist religion and faith-healing. The A.A. meeting room has a revolving door. The therapists
column18: judges
column19: and parole officers (many of whom are themselves hidden members of A.A. or N.A.) continually send new people to A.A.
column20: but those newcomers vote with their feet once they see what A.A. really is. Even A.A.'s own triennial surveys
column21: conducted by the A.A. headquarters (the GSO)
column22: say that:  81% of the newcomers are gone within 30 days
column23: 90% are gone in 3 months
column24: and  95% are gone at the end of a year.  That automatically gives A.A. a failure rate of at least 95%. But the GSO does not count all of those people who only attend a few meetings before quitting -- they don't qualify as "members". (That amounts to "cherry-picking".) If we included them
column25: then the numbers would be much worse.    First there is the propaganda technique of "everybody's doing it": "AA or a similar Twelve-Step program is an integral part of almost all successful recoveries".  That is a complete falsehood. The vast majority of the successful people recover without A.A. or any "support group". It's what "everybody" is doing.  Then they use the propaganda techniques of use of the passive voice and vague suggestions: "It is widely believed that not including a Twelve-Step program in a treatment plan can put a recovering addict on the road to relapse."  It is widely believed by whom? And what do those unnamed people know? What are their qualifications? Are they doctors? Medical school professors? Or salesmen for a 12-Step treatment center? Why should we care what some unnamed invisible fools allegedly believe
column26: anyway?  The authors also use the propaganda technique of fear-mongering: you will be "on the road to relapse" -- you will probably die -- unless you practice Bill Wilson's Twelve Step cult religion.  And then the fluff-headed Pollyanna attitude is outrageous: Just going to the wonderful A.A. meetings is supposedly all that is needed to fix some alcoholics.  But since A.A. has a zero-percent success rate above and beyond the normal rate of spontaneous remission
column27: that cannot possibly be true.

I had read elsewhere that the only thing to recommend this book was the fact that it was light. I have to agree. As an aside
column2: the comments on the local birds would not pass any children's needs. Example- they comment that we are now obviously nearing the coast as we now start seeing seagulls.The graphs for distance and elevation are not nearly as accurate or as detailed as those available for free at many of the hostels. The info is often so poor that I have serious doubt that the authors walked yhe Camino before writing the book. they definately did not spend many nights staying in any of the refugios

column1: This is a rather peculiar film for Seagal
column2: and the first thing that should be pointed out to any Seagal fan contemplating whether or not to give this one a try is that this is really not an action film.  Seagal only has a couple fight scenes in the whole film and they are all extremely brief.  In fact
column3: they are extraordinarily brief
column4: though thankfully free of wirefu.    Though Out of Reach is by no means a total failure (it's actually pretty entertaining

column6: and some of the scenes are well done)
column7: the script nevertheless exhibits some problems and plot holes.  This film is a drama about a nature nut (Seagal) who roams the forest looking for injured animals.  He has a pen pal in Poland
column8: a young girl
column9: and when he hears that she will no longer be able to correspond with him he becomes so upset that he travels abroad to look for her
column10: even though he really has no reason to suspect that anything is wrong with her.  This brings up the main problem with this film
column11: namely
column12: a lot of it simply doesn't make any sense.  It turns out that the girl has been sold to a human trafficking ring
column13: and Seagal goes through the motions to save her.  As per usual with Seagal nowadays
column14: he obviously refused to actually finish the production
column15: and so we have the usual dubbing problem here.  It is even more salient than usual in this picture
column16: however
column17: for here we have not one
column18: but several different people dubbing Seagal's voice
column19: none of whom even remotely sound a thing like him!  Here the most frequently heard fill-in for Seagal sounds like a knock-off Benecio Del Toro with a much higher-pitched voice.  As you can imagine
column20: the effect is very humorous.    As stated above
column21: the main problem with this movie is that it simply doesn't make sense
column22: which was apparently realized by the director
column23: as he has
column24: in many scenes
column25: the voice fill-in for Seagal narrating an explanation of what the character is thinking! How obnoxious!   Seagal's character likes to teach codes and ciphers to his pen pal
column26: which she later uses to communicate with Seagal.  What makes no sense is that every time she leaves a message for Seagal
column27: the villian
column28: ineptly played by Matt Schultz
column29: sees the girl doing it and yet leaves the message for Seagal to find! In one ridiculous scene the girl arranges some caviar on crackers to make a code.  (Apparently three crackers of one kind followed by three crackers of another kind followed by three crackers of another kind means "This is a trap.")  The villain sees her doing this
column30: and
column31: instead of destroying the message (which would make sense)
column32: later has it delivered to Seagal! Huh? In a scene when the girl leaves a message on a mirror telling Seagal where she is
column33: the villian sees her doing it
column34: comments on how clever she is
column35: but then leaves the message!   There are also quite of few mistakes in this film
column36: several of which are laughably obvious.  At the beginning and end of this film
column37: for example
column38: Seagal has long hair which looks like frizzy
column39: black cotton candy being pulled off the back of his head.  During the rest of the film
column40: however
column41: he has short hair.  At the end
column42: after some BS macho dialogue about how Seagal hates taking life but will enjoy killing Schultz slowly
column43: each character uncocks his pistol even though Schultz's pistol does not have an external hammer to uncock
column44: and even though in the very next closeup Seagal's pistol is still cocked! After a sword fight
column45: which ends on a classic move from older chambara films
column46: notice that there is clearly no blood on the floor
column47: and that then
column48: all-of-a-sudden
column49: there is a huge trail of blood between the two characters.    In the finale
column50: the above-mentioned sword fight
column51: the camera cuts between closeups of the two characters to faraway shots that are clearly of someone other than Seagal.  This brings up another frequent complaint of many Seagal fans: his overuse of stunt doubles.  It's almost so bad now that one could say that he doesn't even film his own fight scenes now.  Have you ever noticed that in Lord Steven's early films
column52: when there was a fight scene the camera would pull back and let you see his moves? Now what happens? The camera gets as close as possible
column53: shows some shots of his face grunting
column54: shows some arms playing paddycake
column55: then pulls back showing some fighting while never showing Seagal's face.  Ever wonder why? It's because
column56: surprise
column57: surprise
column58: that's not Seagal doing the fighting.    In the gun fight
column59: which is actually a very decent action scene
column60: watch Seagal as he enters the room.  His character enters the fight by doing a foward aikido roll
column61: which is probably the simplest move in aikido
column62: though it is obvious that it is not Seagal doing the roll.  What is even more irksome is that both at the beginning and the end of the film
column63: which shows Seagal's character "roaming the forest looking for injured animals
column64: or whatever, it is clearly not Seagal that we see walking through the forest.  Was he afraid that he'd trip over a branch and injure himself? Was he afraid he'd be attacked by an injured animal in the woods? I don't know.  What is likely the case is that Seagal again refused to finish the shoot and some scenes had to be constructed after-the-fact, using another actor, in order to make the film work.  I'm really not bashing Seagal, I'm merely complaining because these are persistent types of flaws in his recent films that could VERY easily be fixed.    Be on the lookout for the bizarre scene when Seagal goes to the post office.  The postal worker calls Seagal Mr. Delacraw
column65:
or some such bizarre name, even though his character's name is actually Billy Ray Lancing.  Seagal then proceeds to mumble some French to the man, and then suddenly adopts a cajun accent.  This scene is downright strange.  What is also strange is how Seagal is dressed in this scene--like some kind of New Orleans Anne Rice fan, vampire wannabe in a strange, black fur coat.  I don't know, at least it's good for a laugh.   If Seagal continues in this manner he will quickly find himself unemployable.  The only truly schocking thing is that this hasn't happened yet.  He shows up late to shoots, leaves early, refuses to finish productions, and yet people keep hiring the man.  He repeatedy refuses to do the requisite work for a complete production.  He needs to start finishing his films.  In closing, Out of Reach only has two VERY brief fight scenes, but they are somewhat well done.  Seagal actually takes a few blows in the climatic fight, which is a very nice change and certainly makes his character seem more human.

column1: I am a Jane Austen fan. I love Pride and Prejudice and there are three very good to marvelous adaptations of that great novel. However

column5: but the one who knows the difference between right and wrong. She is mentored by her uncle
column6: the righteous and honorable [and I don't use the terms loosely] Sir Thomas Bertram. Somehow
column7: the adaptation of this great novel has twisted Sir Thomas into a sadistic
column8: sexual pervert. Moreover
column9: Fanny is constantly babbling to us in Jane Austen quips that are not part of this novel. They simply missed the point of the book.  The acting is okay. The settings are okay. The directing is sad. But the sense of disappointment and betrayal by perverting the essential theme of the book has left a very sour taste

column1: As one of the reviewers noted in his review
column2: I too have given many postive marks to those who have given five-star reviews for this novel; because some reviewers have made very good arguments in defense of this novel. [I never give negative marks on anything
column3: even if I don't like a review
column4: but I do give plenty of positives] Therefore
column5: before you begin to throw the bricks and sling your arrows at me
column6: please let me try and explain why I gave this book such low marks. First of all
column7: I have tried to read--or at least decipher "Finnegans Wake" on four different occasions. I see from some of the reviews that anyone who attempts to disagree with this novels merits gets pelted with negative marks. For those of you who enjoy this novel
column8: good for you! I do not profess to be as knowledgeable as some of you may be on this books merits. But I DO KNOW WHAT I LIKE! And I did not like this novel.  I first tried reading "Finnegans Wake" when I was in High School [it was not required reading] because I heard so much about it that I wanted to read something challenging. And challenging was an understatement. Realizing I was young
column9: I attempted it much later while in the military. As if military life were not frustrating enough. It was not until I entered college
column10: where I was reguired to read the novel
column11: that I did so with true earnest: Due to the fact that I had to write an essay on the novel. I did receive an A minus on the paper. However
column12: to be honest
column13: this was after profusely littering the paper with as much b***s***
column14: that to me Joyce littered his novel with. My professor must have seen some great merit in this essay---at least I felt so at the time.  However
column15: wanting to truly understand the novel
column16: I decided to REALLY try and capture what Joyce was trying to write. This too led to my dislike of the novel. Not so much with the books difficulty [although that was a problem]
column17: but with the simple question: Is it really worth reading? My answer? No! For me a novel has to give me that quality of enjoyment that makes the journey a delightful one. It has to capture my soul! This novel never did capture my soul. Give me unabridged editions [the only ones I read] of "The Count of Monte Cristo" by Dumas

column20: my favorite author

column1: I am 88. All my life I have loved my English History & the English Countryside. I have travelled in all the old 52 Counties of England & Wales. Against this background I find that Alison Weir has written the best historical Biography & the best History I have ever read. Of the criticised detail; for me
column2: the Topography is a bonus. Overall the detail provides the facts. Most Professional Historians patronise the lay reader by relegating the facts to references or footnotes. Then by a deliberatively cultivated oersonal style they present their interpretaions of the facts as the correct history. Alison Weir allows the reader to make his own interpretation of the facts as well as a judgment on her own interpretation of them. I have not yet even read all the book - as you know its delivery was delayed - but I have read enough to know that each remaining page will continue to give me increasing delight. I end with one of many personal experiences reading this superb book.        "In August 1924 I had a family seaside holiday at Walton on the Naze. One evening there was an adventurous expedition with other families to walk 'Round the Point'. As a child of 6 I remember clearly seeing in the evening sunlight the grassy mound with a few rocks where the castle once stood. No mention was ever made then or later to this being the place where Isabella had spent her first night in England on her return. In fact our families' expedition was a memorable occasion as there were several children for the adults to safeguard & we were nearly cut off by the incoming tide. Now my memory of that shingled shore is enhanced
column3: not by nostalgia
column4: but knowledge.

column1: I picked this book up because I was running out of decent mystery novels
column2: and figured I was primed to love it given my obsession with the outdoors as well as mysteries.   It only gets two stars because I actually made it through. And I only got through it because I had nothing else to read.    I know Nevada Barr is a "name
column3: and judging by the number of her books stocked in my local bookstore, a popular one. But I could list the things that are wrong with her writing for...well, let's just say more space than Amazon is going to give me for this review. Her prose is bad. Her imagery is unlively (and if you're going to write about a landscape like Anna Pigeon's, you sure as hell ought to be able to write it). Her characters range from the merely flat to the utterly ridiculous (Anna's romantic progression through this book: Oh
column4: I am widowed and my life will never be the same without my husband" to "Oh
column5: it might be fun to be a lesbian" [an out-of-the-blue idea the author never bothers to resolve] to "Let me have a fling with this random man
column6: who
column7: by the way
column8: has as much character as a cardboard cut-out").   Worst of all
column9: she cheats. I guess mystery writers don't have an official code
column10: but according to the Dorothy L Sayers model
column11: Thou Shalt Not Give the Detective Clues Not Given To The Reader. A mystery novel is no fun if the puzzle isn't there for you too. Of course
column12: if Nevada Barr had given us all the evidence she gives Anna Pigeon
column13: there wouldn't be a mystery to have a novel about. Her cheating merely covers up her inability to produce an engaging and puzzling plot.   This was a pathetically sub-par book for the amount of attention it and its sequels have received. If you're looking for an amazing female detective
column14: check out Laurie R King's two series
column15: one about Sherlock Holmes' feminist partner Mary Russell (as unlikely as it sounds
column16: and more than good enough to make up for it)
column17: and the other about San Francisco cop Kate Martinelli. If you want a book about living in the desert
column18: I'd suggest Edward Abbey's _Desert Solitaire_ (it even has a brief appearance by a dead body)
column19: or his hilarious eco-terrorist adventure _The Monkey Wrench Gang_.   Anything but this

column1: Please do yourself a favor and avoid this book. This is the fourth edition and perhaps the worst introduction to fluid mechanics book ever printed. I am a PhD student and have had many courses in fluids. This book is riddled with errors and mistakes. The theory is correct but the derivations of certain equations and the solutions to many
column2: many
column3: many problems are wrong! I cannot believe these errors have survived to the 4th edition. Another reason to avoid this book is because the solutions provided with instructors make great leaps in solving problems. Many of the solutions state "this problem requires a laborious derivation and is much too hard to solve" or something to that effect! I also assist in teaching many intro fluids classes and this makes life miserable. Please use the 5th edition (or any other fluids book for that matter.

column1: Years ago I watched a young comedian I hadn't viewed before on a TV special from the Montreal Comedy Festival.He was a wow
column2: with a devastatingly and savagely funny piece on the Gulf War which had just ended.Sadly having switched on part way through the piece I never found out who the comic was.I ached to be able to get hold of the piece on video and searched in vain for years looking for it.The comic was Bill Hicks and now
column3: as then
column4: his take on America and its place in the world has never been more relevant.This DVD contains some of that early footage
column5: along with a great deal of his subsequent material.You don't always have to be totally in sympathy with views (his stance as a militant smoker for example) to find him seeringly funny.A man who makes you laugh whilst challenging a great many widely held assumptions.Watch Bill and you realise how trivial a great deal of contemporary comedy has become.We need more comics like him.

column1: I remember hearing about this book by the great patriot Sean Hannity sometime in 2001
column2: then it was a mere idea. From that time on
column3: until August 20th 2002
column4: I waited for what I thought would be the greatest book of all time. I remember seeing the cover art and hearing about the title: "Let Freedom Ring" with not just a picture of Sean Hannity on the cover
column5: patriot that he is
column6: but also a flag. I loved it
column7: couldn't be more happy.  Well
column8: the day of the book's release
column9: I took a day off work (i've never missed a day of work before in my life)
column10: and rushed to get this book. It looked better than I ever imagined.  With the flag on the cover and the title of "Let Freedom Ring
column11: I thought, finally, technology has caught up to our patriotism. I expected a book filled with flags, flags with sound effects. Maybe some firework sound effects.   Boy was I wrong. I opened the book only to the colors black and white. No red. No blue. No stars and stripes. I quickly turned the pages, looking, searching for flags. I found none, no sound effects either, no fireworks.   At that point, I went into a 4 year long depression. I nearly committed suicide at several points. It's only now that I can bring myself to review this man's book, patriot that he is.   I say this so you know what you're getting yourself into. There are no flags, no stars and stripes, no fireworks, no sound effects.   I have since recovered, but only because of old stars and stripes. I went back to teaching last year, not fully recovered, and my colleagues, knowing how much I love America and the STARS AND STRIPES, suggested I have my class do a research project: find the most patriotic book ever made.   The methodoloy was simple: A book made out of flags with flag pictures would score high, a book that was not made out of a flag or flags and had no pictures of flags would score the lowest.   We found some very good books and they did cheer me up. The one that was the most patriotic by far was a book called President Jesus: How Jesus Wrote the Constitution
column12: Freed the Slaves
column13: and Won World War II." Its published by a small church in Texas. I was very proud of my students for finding it. It has brought countless joy to my life. Along with the book
column14: made entirely out of a flag

column1: This fat volume about food and cooking
column2: packed with anecdotes and trivia and stories
column3: is amusing but completely unreliable.  As a source of information about the history of food
column4: it is useless.  Many of the assertions of fact here are questionable
column5: and none of them are footnoted so you can check them out. The author seems to have taken snippets from here and there (mostly
column6: apparently
column7: from French sources)
column8: sorted them thematically
column9: and uncritically assembled them into a continuous text.  No doubt a large proportion of the assertions here are true
column10: but there is no way of telling the difference between the true ones and the others!  What's more
column11: the translation is poor.  Not only are some gallicisms rendered word-for-word (and so only intelligible if you translate them back into French)
column12: but there are no translator's notes for topical references.  I cannot recommend this book for anyone seriously interested in the history of food

column1: Robert Johnson was one of the most enigmatic bluesmen of the 20th century and his life is still a mystery today.Fans only have two grainy pictures of Johnson and various accounts of the mans' life by those who knew him and those who purport to have known him.Having died at the age of 27 by poisoning only adds to the legacy.Johnson
column2: like many of his contemporaries in that early century era
column3: liked women and whiskey and that became his undoing...a jealous husband poisoned his drink and sent Johnson off into the history books forever.In this documentary
column4: other bluesmen will tell you what Johnson was all about
column5: right up to those final hours but some of their testimony is questionable
column6: as was Johnsons' entire life.But the music is there and it lives up to the Johnson image. Many songs are haunting (Hellhound on My Trail
column7: Come On In My Kitchen) and many are sad (Drunkenhearted Man
column8: From Four Til Late)but they all carry Johnsons'unique stamp on the blues. One listen and you'll hear it.Danny Glover's narration is compassionate and blues musician Keb Mos' silhouetted figure makes you feel that you are watching actual footage of Johnson himself. Good stuff..

column1: I am a keen reader of music biographies
column2: and this without a doubt or even a close contender
column3: absolutely the worst I have ever read. The subject of the book is fascinating
column4: it is the author that is the problem here.  David Bret is surely the most pretentious man to have ever put pen to paper. He doesn't seem to feel that a page is complete unless it has at least one "phrase francaise" in italics on it
column5: where surely the English word would suffice. I speak French
column6: so I can understand him
column7: even though I find it extremely frustrating
column8: but not everyone with an interest in Morrissey is bilingual and this is extremely alienating to the reader. It doesn't stop there though. Despite Bret's assertion that Morrissey doesn't speak a word of French
column9: "not even a `merci' in-between songs at a concert"
column10: he gives Chapter 6 a French title- "On ne badine pas avec l'amour". Quite why this is appropriate for an English language biography on Morrissey is beyond me frankly. All I can think of is that David Bret wants the whole world to know that he can speak French. Well done David
column11: give yourself a pat on the back.   Throughout the book he constantly creates comparisons between Morrissey and the French singers (and friends of David Bret)
column12: Edith Piaf (who I have at least heard of) and Barbara (who???) which quite frankly do not appear to be there. In my opinion
column13: the low point of the book is when he claims that
column14: "Few songs better sum up Morrissey's life than [.....] `There's a place in hell for me and my friends'
column15: later adapted into French by this author for Barbara" and then proceeds to quote his French translation rather than Morrissey's own words!!!! This sort of self-indulgence is absolutely inexcusable. Another exercise in self-indulgence comes at the start of Chapter 5. Each chapter starts with a quote
column16: usually from Morrissey himself or from a music journalist
column17: but in Chapter 5 we are treated to a quote by none other than Mr David Bret!! This is surely journalism at its absolute worst.  It's not even as is there is a decent biography lurking underneath all the pretension. A few dates
column18: excruciatingly dull descriptions of certain concerts in minute details
column19: and a frankly boring analysis of Morrissey's songs is pretty much all there is to this lamentable biography. The whole book tells us far more about the author than it does about Morrissey
column20: it is littered with his own opinions
column21: such as the pointless part where he informs us what his second favourite Morrissey song is
column22: yet strangely without ever mentioning his favourite
column23: he tells about his own godmother and about how the famous Barbara named a character in a play after him
column24: yet it is very thin on actual content. He mentions an interview that Morrissey did with a magazine that was successful due to "the fact that [the journalist] published his comments verbatim [...] without attempting to draw attention to himself
column25: as too often happens with the music press" Surely this must have been written with a trace of irony
column26: as this book is the worst example that I have ever seen of an author being more concerned about drawing attention to himself than his subject.  Then of course there is the issue of sexuality. Looking at reviews of David Bret's other books seems to suggest that he has a certain fascination with homosexuality and bisexuality
column27: so of course he has a field day with Morrissey
column28: going over throwaway comments and hearsay repeatedly
column29: without of course managing to draw any conclusions.   All in all this is a deeply unsatisfying attempt at a biography. In the first half of the book he jumps around from the 80's to the 90's and then back again
column30: until you have no clue where you are
column31: and then in the second half he seems to just rush through it as if desperate to finish. Maybe he was getting as bored of it as I was. His research seems to have extended only to looking under his bed through all his back issues of a certain French rock magazine and picking out quotes from Morrissey
column32: and he has certainly never spoken to the man himself. He actually includes a quote from Morrissey talking about the first edition of this book when it came out
column33: "It's unsettling to read supposedly factual accounts of you and your life from people who have never come within twenty feet of you"  Although after reading this book I feel I know absolutely nothing at all about Morrissey
column34: I am absolutely certain he would LOATHE both the book and its author. David Bret is too obsessed with himself
column35: Barbara
column36: and the fact that he can speak French to actually engage us or tell us anything we want to know. Oh yes
column37: and the `extensive' discography at the back doesn't even contain Vauxhall and I. Utterly pathetic

column1: Taking Albert Pike as my cue
column2: Morals and Dogma is far more candid about the origin of the Craft than this book.  First of all
column3: searching for the origin of Freemasonry (or at least its preservation) amongst the Knights Templar is preposterous.  There is no evidence the Knights Templar possessed
column4: preserved or advocated any gnostic gospels or secret teachings of Jesus.  This is an anachronism since the gnostic gospels have only gained notoriety in our time.  The Knights Templar were a bunch of mercenaries who had purely mercenary interest when they safely guarded pilgrimages to the Holy Land.  They were good investers and eventually became creditors.  With this money they purchased land in France.  The French King coveted this wealth and property and so spread the libel about the Templars being heretics in order to use the Pope to get rid of them so that the French King could confiscate the Templar's property.  The Pope at the time even regretted that he tried them for heresy.  The Templar origin only operates as misdirection.  I don't know if this is deliberate
column5: although it is hardly unlikely that it isn't deliberate.  Afterall
column6: masonic texts clearly spell out the Kabbalistic origin of freemasonry.  Even the legend of Hiram Abif and Solomon's temple are ostensibly Juwish and should not be disregarded and eclipsed by this Knights Templar nonsense.  Freemasonry is a gnostic religion.  Specifically
column7: its gnosticism borrows heavily from juwish sources
column8: such as the Kabbala.  The pythagorean theorem
column9: and other nonjuwish notions are merely trappings that have been added on to the Kabbalistic core of this gnostic cult.  With regard to Egyptian mysticism
column10: I find it unlikely that it was transmitted to the Freemasons over the centuries since it was only recently that Egyptian hieroglyphics were deciphered by Champollion (1790-1832).    The only record we have of Jesus' life is the four Gospels (There are of course Roman and Greek and Jewish sources such as Tacitus
column11: Lucan
column12: Josephus and the Talmud; but
column13: I'm referring to "eye witness accounts").  Outside of the record His disciples left us
column14: there is no other sources of what Jesus said or did.  Therefore
column15: to presuppose as Christopher Knight does that he has superior historical materials than the writings of Matthew
column16: Mark
column17: Luke and John
column18: and the rest of the New Testament
column19: is the epitome of nonsense.    Don't waste time with this book.  It leads you on rabbit trails.  It has countless more errors than this which I need not go into.

column1: Bart Ehrman's attack on Dan Brown's DaVinci Code raises as many questions as it answers
column2: prompting a diligent student to write an attack on Ehrman's attack on Brown. Needless to say this might engender an infinite series of attacks on attacks
column3: so caution is the best approach. Nonetheless
column4: let's look at some of the errors that Ehrman commits while trying to give us the "truth and fiction" in the DaVinci Code. I'm focused on a single chapter (Jesus
column5: Mary Magdalene
column6: and Marriage) to keep this review to a minimum.  Ehrman asserts that "most of Jesus' followers
column7: and certainly his closest followers
column8: were men (p. 145)."  We'd all agree with that
column9: but before we take it for granted
column10: you must consider that the gospels were written by men with an obvious bias against women
column11: typical of the times. So it should be said in fairness that our impression that Jesus' most active followers were men comes from the stories told by men. In the rare case of a gospel by a women (the Gospel of Mary)
column12: for example
column13: his closest adviser is a woman
column14: not a man. Hence Ehrman's "history" may not reflect the "truth" but merely the opinion of the men.  Ehrman urges us to "recall the saying of Jesus preserved for us from Q...(p. 146)." Someone call the Press! Apparently Ehrman has discovered the Q document. That warrants a major press conference. I was under the impression that Q was a hypothetical document
column15: but now Ehrman apparently is able to find sayings that have been preserved in it. This type of thinking is sloppy and doesn't belong in a serious book.  Ehrman uses a passage from Matthew (19:28) that says the disciples will be seated on 12 thrones to judge the 12 tribes and he concludes that "The future rulers of God's people would all be men (p. 146)." That would assume that all the disciples were men
column16: which is by no means the clear case. It's rare for any of the gospels to give the names of all 12 disciples
column17: and some gospels give the names of as few as 7. So who knows who the other 12 were. And certainly there are gospels which talk about Mary being a disciple
column18: and she's not a man. So Ehrman's conclusion is faulty.  Ehrman claims "Of course there were not many Epicureans or Cynics in Jesus' immediate environment of Palestine... (p. 150)." Needless to say there is no citation for this assertion. That's because you probably couldn't find one. Cynics were known for their wandering
column19: and it's hard to believe that there were not cynics visiting Sepphoris or Caesarea which were major cities
column20: and Sepphoris was well within Jesus' "immediate environment." By the way
column21: the word Palestine was adopted nearly 100 years after Jesus' death
column22: so it's more than curious to find Ehrman talking about Jesus and Palestine.  Ehrman spends a lot of time questioning whether or not Jesus was married and he continually asks the question - "Why would his wife never be mentioned? (p. 153)" Apparently Ehrman has forgotten that the gospels were written by Christians who belonged to sects that were in competition with the sect that was represented by Jesus' family. It's for this reason that the writers slanted the gospels to paint the family in a negative light
column23: as Jeffrey Butz has so brilliantly pointed out in his book The Brother of Jesus. If these same authors went to so much trouble to denigrate the brothers and sisters of Jesus
column24: to what lengths would they have gone to remove any traces of his wife and children (Some scholars believe that the wedding at Cana is such a trace)? For if he had been married and had children
column25: Christianity would have developed in a dramatically different way. While I am not arguing here that this is the case
column26: any adequate discussion of the  situation surely must raise this possibility. Ehrman
column27: however
column28: for whatever reason
column29: neglects to mention it.  Ehrman claims that "Magdalene indicates her place of origin - the town of Magdala... (p. 154)." Yes
column30: that's one theory. But only one. And not a particularly good theory since it wasn't called Magdala anyway
column31: but Magadan (Matthew 15:39)
column32: and it's hard to see how you go from Magadan to Magdalena. A better theory has been put forward by Margaret Starbird who believes that Migdal (the ancient name for the city
column33: which means tower
column34: becauser there was a fish tower there) refers to the fact that Mary "towered over" the other disciples. In other words
column35: a nickname for "Mary the Great". Whether you subscribe to Starbird's theory or not
column36: it deserves to be mentioned. But
column37: in fact
column38: it is in keeping with Jesus' tendency to give his disciples funky names (Rocky
column39: the Brothers of Thunder
column40: the Daggerman) rather than place names.  Ehrman claims "We do know of Jewish men from the time and place of Jesus who were single... (p. 155)" yet he fails to list a single one. Why? Because they are so few. It was inconceivable for a Jewish rabbi aged 30 in the 1st Century to be unmarried. William Phipp's excellent book Was Jesus Married provides good scholarship on this topic. Ehrman claims to have read it
column41: but apparently he skipped that chapter.  Ehrman makes a school boy's error when he claims that the Essenes were celibate (p. 156). While it is true of one sect within the Essenes
column42: there was another sect
column43: noted by Josephus
column44: who were married and allowed to reproduce.  These problems are not minor points. Yet even if they were
column45: their sheer number is disturbing in a work that professes to separate "truth" from "fiction" in the works of another author. When Ehrman is working from such a self-exalted platform
column46: it behooves him to insure that his own material is beyond reproach. This Ehrman does not do.

column1: For wrestling fans it is obvious that an autobiography by this legend is a must for the collection. But what is missing from his chapter on WCW leaves a big gap that cannot be ignored and ultimately detracts from the work.  There was an angle aired during the Ron Simmons v Lex Luger "press conference" for the heavyweight title match where Lex uses a disgusting racial slur to draw heat (of the cheapest kind). The slur actually made it on the air on cable
column2: but was cut when shown through syndication.  Watts spends several pages on why he felt Simmons deserved the push to wear the championship strap
column3: but fails to mention anything about the angle used that perhaps was the worst ever from a major promotion in a business not known for good taste.   Simply
column4: did Watts have a hand in creating the script? If he did
column5: why did he feel he needed to fuel the fire of racisim to gain heat for the match? And
column6: if Watts did not have anything to do with the angle
column7: he certainly would have a recollection and opinion the issue.   Watts remembers conversations he had with wrestlers like Sting concerning the use of steroids and has opinions on a wide-range of subjects
column8: hence not addressing this issue really questions the validity of the entire book.  The most moving section is excerpts of letters from young people when Watts was running the UWF. The words coming from youngsters with oftentimes terminal illnesses is very powerful. It shows the impact that wrestlers back when they worked territories for significant periods of time. They truly were seen as stars like pro baseball and football players & not like the cartoon characters that are seemingly pushed today.  I simply wish Watts did not suffer amnesia on an issue that defined not only his management of WCW
column9: but himself as a person.

column1: First of all
column2: I am a fan of Madonna's music (not all of it
column3: but a lot of it) as well as a huge ABBA fan.   Now I realize that sampling has been very successful for many artists... and apparently it is here as well
column4: but why can't these producers make something more intriguing or dynamic?   Gimme Gimme Gimme (the ABBA song that is sampled here) is a fairly simple song to begin with (as many ABBA songs are) but the complicated arrangements (both vocally and instrumentally) are what made ABBA's songs interesting and fun to listen to.   But taking a few bars of the original song
column5: repeating it over and over and over
column6: adding a dance beat
column7: various other musical effects and a new melody does not add up to a pop masterpiece.   I think she would've been better off either following a similar chord progression to Gimme Gimme Gimme or just doing a cover...  Perhaps Benny and Bjrn should've stuck to their strict "no sampling" rule here!   For some reason many of today's dance/pop songs get too caught up in the production and lack any real substance... A good example of a radio-friendly dance/pop song with a somewhat complicated chord structure is Acoustic Alchemy's "So Kylie" on their American/English album (the song sounds simple enough but if you really listen to what's going on
column8: you'll notice subtle chord changes and a really nice progression).   Now I'm not going to say "Hung Up" is a terrible song
column9: because everyone has their own taste.  But I'm sorry to say it just doesn't do anything for me..
