column4: and Marie Leveau are part of a secret society of demon-busters dedicated to fighting incursions of the Lovecraftian mythos into our world. There are cameo appearances by famous mystics A.E Waite and Aleister Crowley. The problem is that first-time novelist Wheeler isn't really up to the task of fleshing out all of these colorful characters. Conan Doyle sort of works as a real-world incarnation of his literary creation and Houdini is not bad
column5: but HP Lovecraft rings false as some kind of steampunk technomystic
column6: and voodoo queen Leveau comes across surprisingly bland. There are also some serious anachronisms. At one point
column7: Lovecraft is described as using a "transistorized" device. Transistors? In 1919

column1: Silone's communist message is outdated. More
column2: he makes the cardinal error to believe that solidarity is a basic human characteristic: 'Bread is made of many grains of corn
column3: wine is made of many grapes
column4: so it means unity. Unity of similar
column5: equal
column6: useful things. Hence truth and fraternity are also things that go well together.' But
column7: man shows only solidarity if there is a 'personal' gain. Pure altruism is absolutely no option in the struggle for survival.  His picture of mankind is static
column8: too rosy and naive. His belief in the proletariat is obsessive: 'the poor are uncontaminated by greed for property.' Hence
column9: he proposes the abolishing of private ownership of land. 'Evil is only everything that prevents millions of people from becoming human.' For Silone
column10: evil is not a basic and intrinsic part of the human character. He doesn't understand that all proletarians want their children to become (not static) doctors
column11: engineers
column12: lawyers
column13: economists ...
column14: in other words 'bourgeois'. In Stalin's Soviet Union
column15: he sees only a fraternity of peasants and workers. The political role of the Catholic Church nowadays is marginalized. In Italy
column16: they even don't have a Christian Party anymore.  Of course
column17: the main character poses certain questions: had that (communist) community not itself become a synagogue? abandoned the critical spirit? the risks of conspirational struggles? His answer is no. He refutes that the communists aspire too to totalitarian power and orthodoxy and that a black inquisition will be followed by a red one. His return to his homeland 'had been basically an attempt to escape that professionalism'
column18: and he has the 'hope of one day playing a big role'.  Like a fanatically convinced Christian missionary
column19: he tries desperately to sell his communist gospel to the poor cafoni. Unfortunately
column20: they are terribly conservative ('it has always been so') and his message falls on deaf ears.  What is left in this book are the struggles against a totalitarian (here fascist) regime and against the butchery of war. It is partly very melodramatic (e.g. the confession at the end) and its main symbolism (a marxist apostle disguised as a priest) irrealistic.  I prefer Silone's more direct and less apostolical 'Fontamara' and recommend highly his masterpiece 'Emergency Exit'

column1: It's a truism that great novels make lousy movies. For evidence of that fact
column2: you need look no further.  As the great Hollywood novel (at least there's no convincing competitor)
column3: it was inevitable that "Day of the Locust" would hit the screen eventually. And when the time came
column4: some effort was made to ensure the job was done right
column5: beginning with the selection of the director
column6: John Schlesinger
column7: a literate British expatriate with a superb track record. But the 70s was the epoch of good intentions gone awry
column8: in film as in everything else.  "Locust" was made during the period when many people considered William Atherton to be an actor. You can see him in a number of major films
column9: his expression never changing
column10: with all the emotional impact of a log. It's one of those things that lends conviction to the claim that the industry runs on herd instinct.  But it's not all Atherton's fault
column11: because nobody comes to life in this flick. Not even Karen Black
column12: one of the most idiosyncratic actresses ever
column13: for all that she's playing a hooker (Karen must have gotten very tired of that kind of role). Not even old pro Burgess Meredith
column14: as her deadbeat old man. Donald Sutherland reveals a flicker or two
column15: for all that he's supposed to be playing a lump. The sole exception is Jackie Earle Haley
column16: who portrays the evil-minded child actor Adore with truly demonic intensity. Maybe they should have let him direct.  It would seem difficult to make scenes like the collapse of a huge Napoleonic war set or an illegal cockfight look dull
column17: but Sclesinger brings it off. I don't know how -- this is
column18: after all
column19: the guy who made the selection of a new wardrobe for Cold War traitor Guy Burgess look enlightening and entertaining in "An Englishman Abroad". Maybe the milieu overwhelmed him. It's happened to other people.  It all comes to a head at the climax
column20: which is supposed to illuminate an apocalyptic painting of the destruction of LA by Atherton's Todd. In a single truly effective scene
column21: the distraught Homer Simpson murders the noxious child actor Adore. And then...  Well
column22: if you want to see the dullest riot scene in film history
column23: here you are. It's as if Schlesinger said
column24: "Okay
column25: this the 30s
column26: and there were Nazis around during the 30s -- so let's make the rioters Nazis!" Thus we get a lengthy sequence in which people wearing very silly masks (they look like a chorus of Leatherfaces from "Texas Chainsaw Massacre") stand in one spot goose-stepping. Every now and then the camera shifts to a masked woman staring through a car windshield. And that's your riot.   To top things off
column27: Schlesinger then gives us a "symbolic" coda that succeeds only in casting into doubt everything we've seen for the past two hours.   Nathanael West had an unbelievably tough career as an author. His publisher went bankrupt a week before "Miss Lonelyhearts" was due to be published. He died in a car crash only a short time after "Locust" appeared. Then they went and made this movie. Remember that next time you start thinking that life is unfair.

column5: I was almost immediately overwhelmed by the complexity of the code samples (many of which do not even compile; they use declaration types that are not supported in any includes......yes
column6: I included all of the proper files and linked them).  The author gives you several pages worth of code
column7: saying "This class does this; this function does one thing
column8: that function does another thing
column9: call this function to...do whatever"...the list goes on
column10: and on
column11: and on.  The author never goes into detail explaining what the code actually does and more importantly
column12: HOW IT WORKS.  He just says "create this object to do this
column13: then call that function" throughout the entire book.  Never does he explain what you are actually doing and why it is important.  It is bad enough that he gives you pages of source code
column14: then he leaves you on your own to make it work.  His writing already assumes that the reader knows DirectX through and through.  Code samples are also incomplete a lot of times and the reader is left with no clue to what a certain variable/object is because there is no declaration.  AVOID THIS BOOK.  IT IS A WASTE OF MONEY

column1: While I realize that many readers enjoy approaching a topic through the author's personal experiences
column2: people like myself will find much of this book self indulgent.    	Other parts of the book deal with the things like the adoption community (see the Families With Children From China website instead)
column3: and the single child policy.    As a long time member of  Zero Population Growth I can hardy be impartial on the latter
column4: but why spend an entire chapter on the single child policy if later on you are going to say that gender ratios in India are even worse?   	 	I expect that one of the target audiences for this book is parents deciding whether or not to adopt from China.  While I myself would strongly recommend it
column5: I am also one of the parents the book mentions for whom the lack of identifiable birth parents was a major selling point.  Of course
column6: many adoptive parents have the opposite desire
column7: and perhaps they might consider places like Korea or Guatemala (Obviously domestic would be even better for those adoptive parents
column8: but it might be considered impossible).    My Korean niece and nephew know what city their biological parents are from
column9: their occupation and why they were given up for adoption. They could probably find their biological parents very easily if they ever chose to (They are in their teens and have no desire to do so as of yet in spite of their parents urging).   Under Guatemalan law the birth mother must remain in contact through the entire adoption process
column10: signing off multiple times
column11: including at the end of the process.    I read of one couple who suffered the heartbreak of a delay because the woman who claimed to be the birth mother failed the blood test so the child was not eligible for adoption.  	With this in mind
column12: the place where this book and I part company is in approaching an adopted child when all you have to go on is one sentence in an adoption report.  I strongly agree with the expert who is quoted in the book as saying "Tell your daughter the truth.  Tell her you don't know where she comes from."  as well as the author's friend who says "I think there is not the looking inward in China that you imagine".   Therefore I wince when the author says about an imaginary conversation with the birth mother that "I imagine this partly out of my own projection and wishful thinking
column13: I know.  I want my daughter to have been wanted." Or that "You have to assume that love was involved."  The vast majority of adoption literature that we have received specifically says not to tell your child that the biological parents loved them.  Even the literature that does recommend  telling  the child that the biological parents loved them then goes on to urge you not to tell your child that giving them up for adoption was an act of love
column14: as love then becomes equated with abandonment.  One psychiatrist was quoted as saying that many of his clients are in therapy because of such statements.   This book never explicitly encourages such statements
column15: but I expect that many readers would take it this way.   				------------------Ed 						Tianan

column1: Alain Danilou's assessment of the dionysiac cults is somewhat naive. The Dionysaic cults are by no means just about free
column2: ecstatic love and religious tolerance. As Ren Girard has shown
column3: these cults are most of all about the sacrifice of an - innocent - scapecoat in order to regularly release the tensions which again and again build up in a society. Pagan societies
column4: which do not know forgiveness
column5: need this form of tension release in order to preserve or reinstate their unity. The origin of the dionysiac cult is the cruel and indeed ecstatic murder and paradox divinisation of the founder of a culture/society. In Indian mythology
column6: for instance
column7: Parusha was torn to pieces and out of the pieces came the four castes. This founding murder is again and again repeated in the dionysiac cult. Archaic forms of this cult used to sacrifice humans
column8: later forms animals. The Holocaust is a modern form of dionysiac ecstasy. Danilou of course does see very clearly that dionysiac ecstasy is tension release. What he does not see or know is that mere tension release is not all that is possible in lovemaking

column1: I am teaching a business math class and was issued this text book by the college.  While reviewing the book I found it to be more confusing than helpful.  I found the majority of the ideas presented in the book to be of common knowledge.  Rather than presenting the concepts in the book in an analytical manner
column2: the author uses a personal narrative to convey the ideas.  The author introduces new concepts with successive chapters
column3: but does not explain how these concepts are derived.  The author explains concepts at face value
column4: rather than explaining how the concepts come about and how to apply them to other situations outside of the ideal situation.  The first 6 chapters or so
column5: out of a total of 22
column6: are a review of basic math skills starting with addition and subtraction of whole numbers and continue to basic uses of percents.  In addition to those 6 chapters
column7: more of the successive chapters become redundant and are not presented in a logical order.  Integrated into the text are numerous amounts of extraneous articles that are meant to reinforce the underlying point
column8: but instead simply add bulk and distraction to the text.  I found that the concepts of the book are poorly presented and are not explained thoroughly.  I would STRONGLY recommend not using this book
column9: especially for a college level business class.  A person with little to no everyday business experience would find this book to be very simple. In my opinion this book is primarily geared to a 9th grade level education in a public school system and not a college level class.

column1: Paul Auster's City of Glass is perhaps the worst read I've experienced.  The story moves at a pace that would make a snail envious; the murder mystery plot is as thin as air and hardly resolves itself; we spend way too many waking hours with the main character sulking around his apartment staring into a toilet bowl in which he has just defficated--I kid you not.  The best part of this novel is the end.  I read with fervor to get to the end in hopes that the author would have the talent to tie everything together and make this experience somewhat valid; however
column2: I was utterly and discustingly dissapointed beyond my wildest dreams.  To all the reviewers and critics who claim this book is a metaphysical
column3: existential tour de-force
column4: I beg wholeheartedly with my very life to differ.  I believe the author had no such thoughts in mind
column5: had no direction when writing this disgrace of a work and it saddens me to see such an unentertaining
column6: dry-dry-dry piece of fiction with one or two not-so-clever plot devices
column7: gather such literary praise.  Like a Rorschach image you can see life
column8: love
column9: death
column10: a myriad of wonderful symbols
column11: and if you would like to believe that the person who put that ink blot on the page intended you to see all of that depth
column12: intepret and dwell in that depth--coming to conclusions and reflecting ultimately on your own life
column13: well
column14: then
column15: good for you.  But in reality
column16: the person that made that Rorschach for you is Auster
column17: and he just ambigoulsy splatted some ink on the novel pages before you with no ryhme or reason and you All bought it...hook line and sinker. This novel is an exercise in an authors ability to take us nowhere
column18: show us little on the way and still receive praise
column19: despite an ending which is refelctive of the entire work
column20: in that it plain and simply: sucks

column1: The theme suggested by the title is fine
column2: but the author does not stick with his agenda. This book is full of erratic observations

column5: Jung remained grounded in the positive values of Western civilisation - including democracy. He did not turn his back on 2
column6: 500 years of Graeco-Roman/Judeo-Christian culture. To allege that he did is sheer nonsense and exceedingly poor scholarship.   Unfortunately

column9: prone to unreason and crippling scepticism. But

column13: that worries many Americans - and platitudes like those served up by Wolin will not make the problem go away.    The zenophobia in Wolin's book is part of the problem - not part of the solution. For Wolin
column14: even Europe is 'alien' - so

column16: non-caucasian cultures? In this sense - a fatal flaw runs through Wolin's book. He fears fascism - but advocates an agenda whereby one culture stands in judgement of every other

column18: in any corner of the world - to protect and assert its alleged superiority - and that
column19: by definition - is fascism. Paranoia and reason don't make good partners.

column1: "The Island of the Day Before" is a sad relic from a talented and brilliant author.  Certainly people will go on praising Eco (as they should)
column2: but TIDB remains a flacid exercise in overplotting.  Eco has become a sort of literary Andy Warhol - selling his name more than his work.  In trying to achieve a Kafkaesque "portrait of an instant"
column3: Eco merely puts on display what was better left as a study or exercise to be burned after his demise.  The Island of the Day Before lacks virtually all of the elements that make a story worth reading.  Indeed
column4: Eco's inversion of the rules of good fiction is the main attraction for his works.  But in The Island of the Day Before
column5: the reader must trudge through all of Eco's autoerotic complexity solely for the sake of that complexity.  Following is a parody of the sort of nonsense that permeates this book:  "Robert opened the door to the cabin
column6: and was confronted with the object of his dread.  From the planked ceiling hung a hemp rope
column7: knotted every three inches with an inverted half-stitch
column8: each pinned through by a tortoiseshell ladypoker scented with ambergris.  At the end of the rope
column9: approximately four feet from the floor
column10: and thus fourteen hands from a point bisecting a line drawn between Robert's right elbow and the cleft of his chin
column11: was a metal hoop.  The rope was fastened to the metal hoop with an overwrapping style
column12: which Robert immediately recognized as the "Bosun's Burgher" favoured by the Patagonian fishermen.  The metal ring was welded to a torus
column13: and the center of the torus circumscribed a small teak box with a brass hasp and seven lotus shaped inlays.  Each of the inlays contained a tiny portrait of one of the seven sybils standing on one of the seven hills of Rome
column14: but only five of the sybils were depicted with their hands upraised.  The other two sybils hand their hands clasped behind their backs.  The first of the sybils with upraised hands was holding a rod
column15: which twisted along its own length
column16: with radial spikes of hexagonal cross section
column17: each of which was terminated by an inverted cusp which was in turn pierced by a crescent.  The ends of the crescents spiralled back in upon themselves
column18: but they alternated
column19: with some facing right and some facing left
column20: and still others
column21: in a trick of the artist's skill
column22: facing directly toward the viewer's navel
column23: no matter where one stood...

column13: in the way it was originally intended to be seen!  5 Stars for the movie - 1 star for the terrible NTSC Region 1 version

column1: This book's biggest failure is its assumption that its readers will share the author's own political views.  Cass Sunstein is a well-known academic
column2: whose articles have proven extremely illuminating and helpful to many.  This book has none of those characteristics.  Though his articles on the regulatory state have changed the way I think about statutory interpretation
column3: I cannot say this book  persuaded me at all.  The author strongly criticizes "fundamentalism" (perhaps better known as "originalism").  He warns the reader that because "originalism" is aligned so closely with conservatives'/Republican's political views
column4: that it must be the case that the originalist view suffers from bias.  The author does not anticipate that some readers
column5: such as myself
column6: are socially liberal
column7: and yet find textualism and originalism appealing.  His arguments thus failed to speak to me-- he tells the reader that originalism= conservatism
column8: and yet i believe in originalism
column9: but am socially liberal.  What gives?    He then takes cheap shots on originalism
column10: which he should know better than to make.  He marches out a parade of horribles that would result if originalism were accepted.  For example
column11: he argues that school segregation may be permissible
column12: the EPA's authority may be proscribed
column13: etc. etc.  He does not take into account many originalist's view (including my own)
column14: that if it were not for the Court's legislating from teh bench
column15: that the political process (via Constitutional amendments) would prohibit discrimination
column16: and expand the scope of agencies' powers.  His myopic view is all the more startling when one reads his defense of "minimalism" (Sunstein's preferred view).  Sunstein states that we should accept the Constitution as it is currently
column17: but that one should take "minimalist" approaches in providing any further changes.  The critics argue that Sunstein is simply happy with the current Constitution
column18: and ergo espouses the "minimalist" view
column19: to which he responds:  "Suppose perfectionsits really can show that their approach produced a number of decisions taht are desirable and that no other approach could have generated.  The principled minimalist responds:  So what?  If the Court had not acted
column20: the democratic process might have done so instead."  Yet
column21: in hypocritical fashion
column22: Sunstein launches into a tirade against originalism
column23: arguing that that approach reaches undesirable results.  As an originalist
column24: I'd argue:  "If the Court had not acted
column25: the democratic process might have done so instead."   Sunstein does not allow originalists this defense
column26: and it is shocking that he would nonetheless use that argument himself.  This is a better book than you will find by the likes of Ann Coulter or Michael Moore.  It is not a bad book
column27: but just very
column28: very disappointing to those who expected more from the author.  Given Sunstein's unbelievably brilliant law review articles
column29: I'm shocked and disappointed by his patently biased discourse in this book.  I refuse to believe that he
column30: in good faith
column31: actually believes the arguments he makes (he argues
column32: for example
column33: that originalism is tantamount to the "rule of the dead";  yet
column34: Brown vs. Board of Education was written by judges who are now dead-- would he suggest that we ignore that decision because those judges are dead?  Surely a man as smart as he understands that we respect legal texts because of the process they went through to attain the status as binding law
column35: and not out of reverence for the dead).  I could not help but feel that this is simply a thinly veiled attack on conservatives.  I do not mind people attacking conservatives-- i'm a minority/atheist/social liberal who also cannot stand "jesus freaks."  But
column36: when an author as accomplished as Sunstein parades a political attack as an academic work
column37: I cannot help but be disappointed.  I give this book 2 stars
column38: and not 1 star
column39: because people who feel insecure in their originalist views should read this book to see that many of the criticisms of originalism are quite specious.  I hope he writes again on the topic-- I would be very interested in reading what he would say about a subject like this if he made a conscious effort to remove his political views

column1: I read the first two chapters
column2: scanned the rest
column3: and decided not to waste any more time; there are too many good books to read. The premise of the writer (de Becker) is that intuition is correct where rational thought fails. He tells the stories of the lady who was attacked in a dark parking lot
column4: the lady whose boy died during an operation
column5: and the one whose son was getting a lot of attention from a pervert. In every case the lady had reason to fear for her or her boy's safety before a bad thing happened. To de Becker
column6: each tale is proof that intuition was right and reason went wrong. The author does not cite his sources
column7: but makes it clear that he is the world's foremost consultant
column8: and gets these stories from people who attend his lectures and TV appearances (on Oprah!). The book might be better if it was all stories
column9: but it is padded out to 321 pages with a lot of hot air. It never happens that anyone is taken by surprise
column10: or has an unfounded suspicion. Becker gives us a slanted
column11: unbalanced view
column12: in trying to ratify the bold claims on the book jacket (how to know if every person your child will ever meet is a threat). The evidence is cooked. The thesis must be rejected. I offer the alternate hypothesis that de Becker pads his pockets selling bogus books to gullible parents.

column1: ***This is a discussion about certain points in the book
column2: and may be considered to some a spoiler
column3: so please do not read if you want to remain surprised about the book's high points and/or outcome.***  I expected to read this book and feel inspired by the obstacles that were overcome by Chris Gardner as he rose from a poverty-stricken child living the hard knock life to a successful adult with many moral achievements. However
column4: this was not the case. Shortly into the book
column5: I came to realize that most of Mr. Gardner's problems were self-created. Sure
column6: his upbringing was a contributory factor to some of his issues. But mostly
column7: he made some very bad choices that resulted in some very bad outcomes.  First
column8: I disliked how he constantly put his mother
column9: the woman who allowed herself and her children to be beaten time and time again by her husband
column10: on a pedastool. This was a woman who went to prison twice
column11: once for welfare fraud and once for attempted murder
column12: yet we are to believe she was the epitomy of moral conscience? In all fairness
column13: it is respectable that Mr. Gardner continued to idolize his mother
column14: even after his rough childhood and the abuse to which he was subjected at home. However
column15: this woman exemplified so many reasons why she was the complete opposite of an ideal role model for a child.  Second
column16: I thought it extremely irresponsible of Mr. Gardner to discuss not being able to afford to put food on the table for his wife and child some days
column17: and in the next sentence to talk about getting high with his buddies to "take the edge off". Certainly the drugs were not always free. Was he spending the family's grocery money on drugs?   Third
column18: I disliked how he rationalized listening to jokes containing the infamous "N" word from the rich oil tycoon
column19: simply because this same man was fattening his pockets at the time. This tells the world that such a situation is acceptable
column20: so long as someone benefits enough to overlook the insulting word. I also found it absolutely disgusting how Mr. Gardner
column21: immediately upon hearing of this oil tycoon's death
column22: sold every bit of stock in the man's portolio
column23: even though he himself admitted that all stock sales should immediately halt once an estate is in probate. Mr. Gardner stated that the oil tycoon
column24: in the days before his death
column25: had requested that all of his portfolio assets be liquidated (never mind the history of 30-35% capital gains)
column26: and that Mr. Gardner was only carrying out his final "orders". I call Mr. Gardner's bluff on this one - he sold that stock just to make a final commission. Mr. Gardner showed a true lack of ethics in this situation.  Finally
column27: and most disturbing
column28: was how Mr. Gardner sent his son to live with Jackie after she had already once abandoned the child. She had proven herself once to be an unfit mother
column29: yet Mr. Gardner sent his son across the country to live with her after he starting achieving personal financial success in Chicago. If his main concern was the welfare of his child
column30: why did he not keep little Chris with him?  Overall
column31: I am completely dissapointed with this book. Mr. Gardner may be hailed as a hero to some
column32: but he is most certainly not a hero to me.

column1: Saw "Hart's War" the other night and couldn't really believe anyone would invest money and time in a film as awful as this one.  This film bombed at the box office and was yanked from circulation after only a few days.   Here are ten reasons why:  1.  This film isn't "The Great Escape" and even though he would probably like to think otherwise
column2: Bruce Willis isn't Steve McQueen.  Even though Willis received top billing
column3: this is a Colin Farrell vehicle.    2.  The vast majority of the target audience of 18-34 year old moviegoing males could care less about what happened during the Reagan administration
column4: much less World War II.  "Hart's War" may just as well be a film about a POW camp during the War of 1812.  Anything with Vin Diesel or the Rock would be bound to sell more tickets.  3.  As far as depicting life in a POW camp
column5: "Hart's War" is pretty much on par with "Hogan's Heroes".  The Germans are nice guys with guns who don't know very much and everyone gets away with just about anything.  Where did the GI's get all those cigarettes
column6: anyway?  4.  Any Stalag Luft comandant worth his weight in sauerkraut would have just as soon killed the Bruce Willis character as look at him.  As depicted in "Hart's War"
column7: the camp commandant (as portrayed by Marcel Lures) would have had a very difficult time maintaining any sort of status as an officer in the German Army.  His collection of American jazz/blues records is a cute writer's invention that has nothing to do with the reality of the situation
column8: or of the type of men who were in charge of German POW camps.  In reality
column9: the Marcel Lures character would probably have been relegated to another type of nazi camp with a pink triangle sewn on the front of his tunic.  5.  The storyline is not completely unbelievable - trials did take place in POW camps
column10: one good example being the POW's who were tried and hung in Andersonville;  However
column11: the whole idea that the camp's commandant would actively participate in such a trial as sort of a Jerry Springer type advocate is ludicrous.  6.  The idea that during the trial
column12: a group of POW's who escape go on a secret mission to destroy a nearby munitions factory is insulting.  Not only did nothing like this ever happen during World War II
column13: it degrades the bravery of those poor souls whose only act of heroism was to survive internment under harsh and sometimes brutal conditions.  The German army simply wasn't that stupid.  7.  I saw this film once and didn't like it.  I thought that maybe the second time would be better.  It wasn't.  8.  Beyond being sheer Hollywood political correctness
column14: "Hart's War" seriously misrepresents many of the more important aspects of internment.  It ignores the real focus of life in such a Stalag which
column15: for most POW's
column16: was just day to day survival.  Also
column17: the soldiers who served in our armed forces during World War II and also happened to be African Americans weren't spineless
column18: hapless dopes.  9.  Bruce Willis playing the same role in variations of "Die Hard" over and over and over again is tiring.  10.  Better films about the same sort of subject matter are "The Tuskeegee Airmen" and "Stalag 17".  Hopefully in a few years
column19: "Hart's War" will be completely forgotten
column20: and these dvd's will be rotting in some landfill.

I can confirm that the cartridges shipped with this photo value pack have a fraction of the ink capacity of normal cartridges. While there is nothing at all that indicates this in any of HP's marketing materials (bad HP) it becomes clear when you install them. The ink level gauges on the printer show much smaller bars for these than the regular cartridges - and indeed they do run out very quickly compared to normal cartridges.   Face it - HP is all about making very large profit margins from selling ink
column2: and they aren't dumb.  If you want to buy an ink combo pack of full cartridges you can search amazon for HEWLETT PACKARD 02 COMBO PACK - you will find this listed as of today at $60 and not that much of a discount vs. buying single cartridges.

column1: I can't believe anyone would give this stroller a good review. We have 10m twins
column2: and have been using the stroller for about 4-5 months. It's terrible.  PROBLEMS:   1. NO SUN PROTECTION. the visors are locked in place. Unless the sun is directly overhead or at your back
column3: it will be beating in your babies' eyes
column4: and you'll need to buy a non-Peg Perego sunshade accessory. 2. HARD TO STEER. It gets stuck going across the lawn and on compacted dirt. If the sidewalk buckles just an inch (common from tree roots)
column5: the stroller is stopped dead in its tracks. It's hard to steer in a straight line
column6: so it's easy to get stuck when going through narrow doorways or down narrow sidewalks.  3. IT'S FLIMSY. The bottom of the storage area underneath stretched and sagged after a month of use. It now drags on the ground and rubs against the wheels even when nothing is in it. The cupholder broke during the first week. 4. HARD TO UNFOLD. It takes two hands to unfold and you have to give it a vigorous shake to get it to completely unfold and snap into position. Don't even THINK about about trying to set it up with a baby in your hands: you need both hands free to deal with this thing. 5. BAD CUSTOMER SUPPORT. The stroller comes with no weight/height/age  suggestions. When we first tried to put our twins in it
column7: they were swimming in it
column8: and couldn't be upright. When we called Peg Perego and asked how big the kids should be to use it safely
column9: the support rep said " don't know."   Yes it's lightweight and folds up nicely. But the light weight is actually a drawback; it means the handle and legs are flimsy and wobbly -- resulting in a stroller that's difficult to steer.   My advice would be to seriously consider jogging strollers. Even if you aren't an active parent -- I'm not -- get something sturdy with big wheels to get you over the dips and bumps and cracks and patches of sand
column10: dirt
column11: and grass that you will encounter.  If stroller size is the most important factor to you
column12: look at "stadium seating" strollers.

column1: Mr. Bloxham does not take into account the effects of the Armenian Revolt
column2: which lasted from the 1890s to 1920. Armenian revolutionary groups
column3: the Hinchaks and Dashnaks
column4: launched a campaign of terror against Ottoman officials and citizens. They began killing Muslims 20 years before the Armenian deportations took place in 1915. Also
column5: from 1915 to 1920
column6: Armenian soldiers
column7: rebels and gangs massacred a half-million Turks
column8: Kurds and Azeris. If we are willing to call what happened to the Armenians a genocide
column9: then what do we call what the Armenians did to the Muslims?   Anyone who seeks to learn about the Armenian/Ottoman tragedy should start with a book published in 1964 by the Armenian scholar
column10: Louise Nalbandian: "Armenian Revolutionary Movements." She wrote her book shortly before the Armenian Diaspora began to politicize their claims to genocide. It doesn't matter to me whether a person believes the Armenians were victims of genocide in 1915. What matters to me is that "academics" such as Mr. Bloxham insist on discussing only one side of this tragic story
column11: and continue to pretend that Armenians did no wrong.  Horrible atrocities were committed on all sides; it is the responsibility of Turkey
column12: Armenia and Azerbaijan to deal with this legacy. In the U.S. and Europe
column13: this issue has become too politicized. Anyone who disagrees with the Armenian viewpoint is automatically labeled a "genocide denier." Unfortunately
column14: most of the media and politicians have naively chosen to support the Armenian genocide claims without conducting their own research. And they choose to believe that "scholars" such as Mr. Bloxham are basing their writings on thorough research that takes the Armenian revolutionary movement into account; such is not the case

column1: When my husband developed acid reflux
column2: it was recommended that he lower his carb intake. As long time lacto vegetarians (no fish
column3: meat or eggs
column4: yes to dairy)
column5: this sounded particularly challenging.  I bought 3 different low carb cookbooks from Amazon a month ago: "Low-carb Vegetarian" by Celia Brooks Brown
column6: "Carb Conscious Vegetarian: 150 Delicious Recipes For Healthy Lifestyle" by Robin Robertson and "The New Glucose Revolution Low GI Vegetarian Cookbook: 80 Delicious Vegetarian and Vegan Recipes Made Easy with the Glycemic Index" by Dr. Jennie Brand-Miller   After a month of consistent cooking I have rarely used Brown's "Low-carb Vegetarian" which is laden with ~50% recipes that use eggs.  There are some great recipes in there if you eat eggs though.  On the other hand
column7: my copy of "Carb Conscious Vegetarian: 150 Delicious Recipes For Healthy Lifestyle" by Robin Robertson is a bit dog-eared already.  Delicious
column8: innovative recipes with new ways to use foods common to the vegetarian and wonderful exploring of unusual but easily available new veggies and protein options.  "The New Glucose Revolution Low GI Vegetarian Cookbook"  by Dr. Jennie Brand-Miller was rich with information and great recipes.  It taught me a lot.   But by far Robertson's "Carb Conscious Vegetarian" is the best.  I will say that I don't know either of these authors and am doing this to help a buyer who may be wondering which one to get...  By the way
column9: a low carb/lower acid diet has really eased the acid reflux my husband suffers from. We eat a main meal during the day and a protein drink at night
column10: even if working: switched when consuming. And I am starting to lose weight...  Hope this helps!

column15: "Billy Budd" is the story of a simpleton who is transferred from a merchant to a war ship due to political circumstances. column16: he ends up killing the accusing man in front of the ship captain (a very intelligent thing to do)
column17: so that he is put to trial and finally hanged. End of story. What remains in between is one of the most pedantic and pointless writing in the History of American literature. We don't even get to know why Claggart was envious of Billy as the narrative is so disperse

column1: This is the over-hyped story of two industries

column6: Motley would have fought this battle even they weren't paid

column1: I am the type of person that ALWAYS buys the extra warranty on whatever I purchase.  However
column2: I started reading the reviews on this company and many people reported that it was four weeks and counting and they still hadn't received their refund check.  I was astonished.  I contacted N.E.W. myself and asked them about this.  With no shame or embarrassment on the part of the customer service reps
column3: I was informed that if I did everything by email
column4: it would take AT LEAST 15 business days (that's three weeks!) to receive my refund check AFTER I sent them the warrantied item.  If I had them send me a pre-paid label for the defective item instead of using my own printer
column5: it would take a week for me to receive and at least a week for them to receive the covered item.  In other words
column6: it would take no less than four weeks to receive the replacement check and possibly up to eight weeks!  I cancelled the contract immediately.  It is just not worth it when you really do the math to purchase this contract.  I would recommend buying a product from a company that first makes a quality product and then back it up with a good warranty and gives good customer service such as Grado
column7: Sennheiser or Koss.  But stay away from these people; that's my feeling and my advice.

column1: In the wake of The Phantom Menace
column2: I was very forgiving.  I honestly just figured it was a sluggish opening to what was sure to be a fantastic set of films.  Sure Obi-Wan had only a supporting role
column3: while Anakin himself barely had that.  They were just setting the stage for the real show.  When I saw ads and trailers for Attack of the Clones
column4: I was sure this was the Star Wars prequel I was really waiting for.  Anakin Skywalker would no longer be some little kid and he would at last take the center stage as a young
column5: lightsaber-brandishing Jedi hotshot.  All the things I used to love to hear about in the old movies
column6: like what a great warrior he was
column7: how he and Obi-Wan Kenobi were the best of friends
column8: and all the grand adventures they had together
column9: all before Anakin's tragic fall to the Dark Side of the Force
column10: would finally be shown
column11: and it would be fantastic.  Boy was I wrong...  By now we've all heard the same criticisms for this film.  The acting is poor
column12: the dialogue is bad
column13: etc
column14: etc...  Those are all very valid arguments of course
column15: and they are enough to hurt any movie.  What really turned me against this film
column16: however
column17: is the simple fact that Anakin Skywalker has turned out to be the single most unlikable "hero" I've ever seen in a major motion picture.  Far from the good person we were told about in the original trilogy
column18: the Anakin we see here is incredibly obnoxious.  He gripes and throws tantrums
column19: usually when his ego is not pandered to
column20: he can't hold his own in a fight
column21: and worst of all
column22: he clearly hates Obi-Wan Kenobi's guts.  So what's Anakin's problem?  Why is he such a crab?  In the movie
column23: Obi-Wan claims that Anakin's abilities have made him arrogant
column24: hence his foul attitude.  Some of the other Jedi also comment about how Anakin has such "exceptional abilities" for his age
column25: and Anakin struts about as if he's owed something for his talents.  Apparently his amazing Jedi powers have lead to our hero to having a bit of a swelled head.  That all sounds very interesting at first
column26: but you can imagine my confusion when every single battle in which Anakin participates involves him getting clobbered.  Indeed
column27: with the exception of a minor scuffle towards the beginning of the movie
column28: all the fights in which Anakin is involved end with either him surrendering at gunpoint or with him just flat out getting his butt kicked.  My favorite example of this is how the climactic lightsaber duel with Count Dooku wraps up with our dashing young hero being shoved over by an eighty-year-old man.  Am I really expected to believe this is the cunning warrior we were told about in the original films?  And more importantly
column29: how can I believe this wimp is the future Darth Vader?  So why the slew of losses for our hero?  It seems like the primary theory is that
column30: like The Empire Strikes Back
column31: since this is the middle portion of a trilogy
column32: the good guys need to get kicked around a bit by the bad guys.  As part of the journey for a hero
column33: Anakin is apparently supposed to "suffer his first defeats" at the hands of his adversaries as he grows as a character.  Just like Luke
column34: right?  Now I'm as much of a fan of the Hero's Journey as anyone.  That's why I love the original Star Wars Trilogy so much
column35: and I'm sure many of my fellow fans out there are the same.  But the real question now is
column36: since this trilogy is going to end on such a dark note
column37: why make our hero suffer so many superfluous defeats halfway through?  Isn't his turn to evil at the end of this new set of films enough of a failure for him to suffer through?  And what major victories has Anakin experienced in the past to justify his multiple defeats now?  If anything
column38: this should have been the movie in which Anakin experiences his biggest and brightest successes.  That way
column39: when Anakin becomes Darth Vader
column40: it really would be a terrible loss and tragedy.  Unfortunately
column41: this movie just tries to imitate the formula of the original trilogy by having the middle installment feature the heroes getting their butts kicked a lot
column42: making the fatal mistake of forgetting that the heroes are already doomed to fail at the end of this whole trilogy.  By the time Anakin actually does turn to evil at the end of the third movie
column43: it's just a great big
column44: "so what?"  So much time is made pointing out that Anakin has some latent evil lurking within him or that he's more of a failure than a hero
column45: his turn to the Dark Side is really nothing special.  Who cares what happens to him?  Anakin didn't fall from grace by the time Revenge of the Sith came around
column46: because there was no grace to fall from in the first place
column47: thanks to this movie.  We were promised a hero
column48: and we got a punk.  That's why I despise this particular chapter so.  When Anakin isn't busy getting knocked around by bad guys or lusting after Padme
column49: the rest of his time is spent grumbling about how much he resents his mentor
column50: Obi-Wan.  At best
column51: Anakin harbors a grudging respect for his master
column52: but it doesn't go much further than that.  Instead
column53: it's made pretty clear that Anakin does not think very highly of Obi-Wan
column54: and he rails on and on about how unpleasant it is being under his tutelage.  At one point Anakin actually accuses Obi-Wan of keeping him from his full potential.  Obi-Wan himself is not so innocent either.  Nothing like the kindly old wizard from the original films
column55: the Obi-Wan here is very snide and has a tendency of rolling his eyes while making sarcastic comments at Anakin's deeds.  Keep in mind this is not just harmless banter when these two start in on each other
column56: this is genuine hostility.  Anakin even refuses to go help Obi-Wan when he gets word that he has been captured by some of the villains.  Only after Padme twists Anakin's arm into going does he make any effort to help his teacher.  These two characters don't look like good friends to me.  In fact
column57: these guys don't seem to like each other at all.  It's really disappointing
column58: because the original films made such a great setup by weaving tales about what a great guy Anakin was
column59: and how he was such a good friend.  Having our two heroes despise each other now totally undermines any drama when they clash at the trilogy's finale.  There's just no reason to care about the death of their friendship now
column60: because this movie killed it before it could even begin.  Not only that
column61: but it totally blows off what Obi-Wan stated about their friendship in the old movies.  Anakin was supposed to be the antithesis of Darth Vader; a good
column62: decent person who was a warm friend and a boon to the Republic.  Now
column63: he just seems to be nothing more than a watered down version of the monster he's destined to become.  It's like George Lucas is congratulating himself for making such a legendary villain in the original trilogy by dropping these little "hints" here and there pointing out the fact that Darth Vader's creation is just around the corner
column64: as if that was something glorious.  What I really don't understand is what purpose all this animosity serves.  It seems like it's supposed to be foreshadowing to their big brawl at the end of the series
column65: but why foreshadow when everyone in the civilized world has known Anakin Skywalker is going to turn against his mentor for more than twenty years?  Wouldn't have setting up a real sense of camaraderie between these two now have made their battle at the end of the next chapter much more tragic and poignant?  Besides
column66: when Revenge of the Sith finally came out
column67: the blistering contempt these two characters clearly harbor for each other in this chapter doesn't even play any kind of a role when Anakin makes his turn to evil.  All the vicious accusations Anakin makes about Obi-Wan holding him back or being too hard on him in his teachings are all just cast aside and contribute absolutely nothing to his decision to turn to the Dark Side.  In fact
column68: it's all forgotten and treated as if it never happened.  Instead
column69: by the time Episode III comes around
column70: we just get a bunch of baloney about how love is somehow the key to the Dark Side (even though it's been established that hatred and anger are the elements of this forbidden power) and Anakin's care for his beloved Padme was the reason for his downfall.  Meanwhile
column71: our two heroes gushed about what a great time they had together as master and apprentice and what good friends they are
column72: despite the fact that this movie was all about showing how volatile their relationship was.  It's a tremendous blow to the continuity of the series
column73: and I get into more so in my review of Revenge of the Sith.  So I ask
column74: what is the point of all their bickering in this movie?  Aside from reminding the whole world about Anakin and Obi-Wan's showdown even though it's already known about it for nearly three decades now
column75: and essentially treating the audience like complete morons
column76: I'm yet to come up with an answer for that question.  Just as we only hear of how Anakin is such a powerful warrior while simultaneously seeing him get beaten over and over again
column77: we only hear of how Anakin and Obi-Wan are friends
column78: while much of their interactions we actually see in the movie involve them arguing or criticizing each other.  Having characters just talk about something in a movie doesn't make it so.  For heaven's sake
column79: movies are supposed to be about showing a story visually
column80: with images on the screen!  It can't just be chatted about!  This movie might as well have been two hours of George Lucas sitting in a comfy chair
column81: reading the script aloud.  That makes about as much sense as what we ended up with.  If something as important as Anakin's skills as a warrior or his friendship with his mentor are just talked about
column82: it doesn't carry any weight compared to what's shown on the screen
column83: especially when all we see is the exact opposite.  Now let me see if I've got all this straight.  Here we have our protagonist Anakin Skywalker:  He gripes and moans about what a jerk his master Obi-Wan is
column84: yet I'm supposed to believe they're close friends.  He boasts and brags about being a super-powerful
column86: yet it seems all it takes to best him is a handful of rickety battle droids.  All this
column87: and I'm expected to be rooting for this chump?  I don't know what George Lucas was thinking when he wrote the script for this movie
column89: one and one does not make three.  Despite all of this

column1: Having read the book by William March many years ago and really liking it
column2: I recently had the chance to see the film version again. It is obviously not as good as the book; in fact it is pretty terrible and laughable.  It's obvious that it's just an opened up stage play; it seems stiff and stilted and stagey; everyone seems to speak loudly as if trying to make their voices reach the upper balconies of a theater. Pretty badly acted all around but the worst is Nancy Kelly. She got an Oscar nomination for this?? All she does is scream or shout her lines in an increasingly hoarse voice and wrings her hands dramatically almost like a character in a Perils of Pauline movie. She is so laughably bad in every scene and her character is just about as stupid. Finally it takes a hammer to the head for her to figure out what's going on.  Patty McCormack and the usually excellent character actor Henry Jones are both pretty one-note in their performances. Enough said. But the saddest is to see the great Eileen Heckart overacting badly as a grieving drunk of a mother. Her histrionics make you want Rhoda to do away with her too. And the neighbor Monica...equally annoying. I kept waiting for Rhoda to shove her down the stairs just to shut up her incessant prattling on about nothing.  This was a huge hit on Broadway and the cast was carried over for the film version; maybe it worked better on stage
column3: I don't know...but it's a pretty awful film; not the classic it's reputed to be. Not a bit of suspense or horror or anything else here to give you chills. Just a chance to watch some good actors like Heckart and Jones stumble around with a silly script and overact like kids in a high school play. It's a lot of fun to watch if your intent is to not take it seriously and to make fun of it. Then you should have a good time.  ****SPOILER FOLLOWS****  Best part? The end when Rhoda gets nailed by a bolt of lightning. Too bad the lightning didn't get her mom at some point early on

column1: I think the book is raising some good questions and is trying to address very important issues and problems in organizational behavior
column2: but the quality of the content leaves plenty room for improvement. The stories and cases that illustrate the concepts of the book are mostly highly artificial and oversimplified

Boom! After that

column1: Mr. Walsh's new book on Stravinsky has some interesting anecdotes and insights into the years in America for the composer but seems to lack real relevance historically.  What seems to be missing from this new book is any primary sources for his many anecdotes. The Stravinsky estate after his death is a matter of public record in the courts
column2: yet Mr. Walsh has not done the research to get the real facts. Why?  There are excellent books by sources much closer to Stravinsky--to say the least Robert Craft's. Craft a twenty year associate of Stravinsky documented just about every waking moment of Stravinsky's life. Referring back to some of Craft's books on Stravinsky I find that Walsh has lifted numerous writings from Craft rather than bringing anything of real interest to life for the reader.  I have to say
column3: this book is not the best work on Stravinsky and I hope other readers will go to better sources for a cohesive and cogent telling of Stravinsky's life and career

column1: The history of corporate finance is a fascinating subject
column2: overflowing with interesting people and dramatic events that affect not only finance but the man on the street.    Unfortunately the authors of this book have no interest in breathing life into the story of capitalism.  Instead what a reader will get is a dry list of facts.  The regulated company evolved into the joint stock company for the following reasons.  The East India Company developed the following innovations.  Its example paved the way for the next step
column3: and so on.  The book has all the feeling of a dull term paper written by a college student who simply summarized the obvious secondary sources.  Each step seems to lead naturally
column4: ploddingly to the next
column5: in a march that seems both uninteresting and inevitable.    While the authors have done an impressive job of bringing many important facts over a broad context together in one volume
column6: that's all they've done.  And I detected a subtle smugness
column7: like that of a Monday morning quarterback
column8: as the authors pointed out flaws in earlier structures.  To me they seemed unaware that the flaws in today's systems will look as obvious to future scholars as those of the past seem now to us.  I also encountered what I considered to be lapses in scholarship (or insight) brought about by the "Ivory Tower" phenomenon of having only a an academic understanding of processes undertaken by others.  The coverage of LBOs is an example.  It's easy in hindsight to go on about the excesses of leveraged buyout era of the 1980s.  Baskin and Miranti cover this fully
column9: detailing many of the problems that arose.  But was there any rationale for the LBOs in the first place
column10: or were they simply the instruments of greedy financial conmen?  On p291 the authors begin one paragraph with the following: "One important method applied by LBO organizers to achieve superior performance was to change ownership structures."  Having lived through that era
column11: I'm aware of how misleading that statement can be.  At the time there were a number of public companies that weren't well managed and had languishing stock prices that not only didn't reflect the firms' potential
column12: but didn't even reflect the value of their current operations.  Traditionally this obvious problem (the stock's trading at $35 and it's worth $60) had no easy solution.  Until LBOs came along (both friendly and unfriendly)
column13: there was little that could be done.  LBO firms were able to convince investors that a company was undervalued
column14: provide a method for quickly realizing this value
column15: and prove that it could be done.  Many decry the fact that jobs were sometimes lost in the process; a point worth considering.  But this doesn't take away from the fact everyone who owns stocks today has a portfolio that's more fairly and appropriately valued because of the rationalizing force introduced by leveraged buyouts.  Valuing these companies wasn't the innovation
column16: any grad student could have done that.  It was coming up with a way to prove that these valuations mattered
column17: and that management would be held accountable for them
column18: that was the innovation.    Now when incompetent management is forced out as a result of an LBO
column19: is that a "change in ownership structure?"  I guess so.  But for me the phrase fails to capture the essence of what is taking place.  Is quickly realizing the value in a company whose stock is trading too cheaply "achieving superior performance?"  I wouldn't call it that
column20: but I suppose an academic might.  The point here is that an intelligent laymen looking to expand his or her knowledge and become interested in a fascinating topic will be poorly served by this type of phraseology.    Not recommended.

column1: I'm not faulting the research
column2: which is comprehensive; it is the format that the author chooses to present this information that is so difficult to digest. On any given page there are as many as 15 different names with barely enough information about each artist to differentiate them from one another. The book is so short and so densely packed that it is difficult to absorb the information. The author uses the regionalization of the Blues as it traveled from the South to the North as his basis for examination; occasionally throwing in lyrics or musical notes to support a point
column3: but their inclusion seems to be haphazard at best. If you are looking for a tremendous amount of information about the Blues this is fine
column4: but if you are looking for an enjoyable read
column5: look elswhere

column1: First let me state that the terms "technotrash pseudo-fiction" are not intended to be negative in the sense that this book is trash to be ignored or thrown away. What is significant here is the genre of technotrash pseudo-fiction. See the other reviews to get a feel for what I am talking about. The book reads like a story
column2: which it is. It offers up that comfort food satisfaction for the mind that many crave--just like pulp fiction! So
column3: if you are looking for any sort of depth or a cut-to-the-chase analysis
column4: this book is a waste of time--in fact
column5: just browse the book here at Amazon and read the reviews. I use the descriptor pseudo-fiction because the book is not fiction
column6: it is just layman science served up that way.  Two stars for being well-written
column7: two stars for lack of depth and far too much fluff

column1: This book was recommended to me by an accupuncturist who did a great job on my back.  I found it contradictory and ultimately confusing to the point of being useless.  Readers are encouraged to diagnose themselves as being damp or dry
column2: warm or cold
column3: with an interior or exterior issue
column4: and with an excess or a deficiency.  (There may be more categories
column5: that's all I can remember now.)  The main problem with the book is that if one is
column6: say
column7: both damp and cold (which Pitchford states is a common combination) then the dietary advice is contradictory.  One chapter says to eat raw vegetables
column8: the next says no.  One says eat meat
column9: the next says no.  One says fruit
column10: the next says no.  One stresses brown rice
column11: the next says very little brown rice.  In addition
column12: being too far along one axis is the same as being the opposite condition.  If you just said "Huh??" then get used to it if you order this book.    Lastly
column13: the big puzzle to me in reading all these 5 star reviews is that not one person (unless there is a review I missed) discusses how their health was improved
column14: how they lost weight
column15: anything!  Isn't that really the proof of a book on dietary recommendations?    Bottom line:  eat whole foods
column16: not processed
column17: organic if possible
column18: and a variety of produce
column19: whole grains
column20: and small portions of lean meat.  I just saved you 700+ pages of reading and $30-something.  And you're welcome.

column1: This book really wasn't at all what I was expecting
column2: or what the title would lead one to believe. The subtitle
column3: "In Search of Grace O'Malley and Other Legendary Women of the Sea
column4: makes it sound as if this will be a biographical account of the life of Grace O'Malley, with supplemental information on other historical female seafarers. Not so. The first two chapters are devoted to the famous pirate queen herself, and Sjoholm only provides the skimpiest bits of information. I knew almost nothing about Grace O'Malley going into the book, and I know little more than that now. The other women included are discussed in even sparer detail, and most of them aren't even real historical figures, but legendary story characters and mythological creatures like mermaids. She even talks about Pippi Longstocking! Not what I was expecting at all...  The Pirate Queen" is actually devoted far more to Sjoholm's travels in search of information on female women of the sea than it is to the information itself. I learned more about Sjoholm and her own life than about the women she supposedly set out to study. She describes the inns she stayed at

She raises more questions than she answers, and I'd need to buy numerous additional books to find all the missing information. You may also notice, given the names, that nearly all the women mentioned are northern European in origin. Sjoholm entirely omits women seafarers active in other parts of the world, such as the famous pirates Anne Bonney and Mary Read who, though from Europe, sailed the Caribbean.  As for Sjoholm's writing style, the book is an easy read, but not a very enjoyable one. Sjoholm's writing is given to an abundance of nearly nauseating metaphors. For example: The lava fields looked like vanilla cake batter poured over thick jumbles of dates

First of all let me say that the overall mystery was boring and I knew the ending very eraly in the book....nothing new to offer here.  I read a lot of series where you can predict what happens but great characters make is worth the reading.  This isn't one of those books.  The mystery starts in such a contrived way!!  19 years ago a murder of two girls took place in Syracuse.  "Bunny" (our protagonist) is not from Syracuse but happens to live there now because her husband is from there.  She is from Long Island and California old money.  But she happens to be in Syracuse now.  At the same time it happens that she is handed a set of dog tags
column2: from her father-in-law
column3: that were found at the murder site.  The tags also happen to be from her cousin-who does not live in Syracuse but happened to be in town at the same time the murder took place.  How contrived is that?  If "Bunny" wasn't married to his son would the tags remained ignored? Could there be a more contrived connection than the tags belonging to her cousin? It is a poor way to get into a mystery. Anyway
column4: anyone who reads mysteries can guess who did the murder quickly.  The real problem I had was with "Bunny" - the main protagonist. What a distasteful unpleasant character she is.  Her whole "stick" is that she hates Syracuse.  From page one she complains about living in Syracuse and it seems not a page goes by without another complaint about living in Syracuse.  Don't get me wrong..I am from Buffalo and left ASAP - but and here's the thing - my complaints about Buffalo are things that are about me or generic. For example
column5: I hate the winters there or  I wanted to move away from my family. But for a lot of people
column6: Buffalo is the place to live.  I get that - to each their own.  But not "Bunny" - oh no not her.  I have read many many novels where the main character wants to leave their present local - be it the big city
column7: the midwest
column8: the farm
column9: the small town..etc.  But "Bunny's" complaints are so nasty.  She puts down how the people of Syracuse live
column10: what they eat
column11: how they dress

column13: what music they listen to
column14: etc.  "Bunny" is a spoiled brat
column15: and a condescending snob and I don't want to spend anymore time with her. I only finished the book to see if she grew up....she didn't.   According to the book jacket - the author's life is very similar to "Bunny's" so I can only guess that "Bunny's" words
column16: thoughts

column14: one of the few songs the producers chose from the early 20th century was "Ain't She Sweet"-- a Roarin' Twenties jazz standard introduced in 1927 by Paul Ash & His Orchestra at the Oriental Theatre in Chicago and thereafter adopted by such entertainers as Eddie Cantor and Sophie Tucker.   Alice Paul was hardly a flapper
column15: nor was she an astute poitical strategist. She was a militant activist whose overwrought contribution to winning the vote for women only complemented the much greater
column16: much more productive efforts of Carrie Chapman Catt (Angelica Huston) and others who had continued the struggle since Seneca Falls in 1848. Catt used Paul's antics to good effect in eventually persuading President Wilson (here
column17: woefully overweight) to endorse suffrage as a route to victory in the Great War. Paul was at most a footnote in the process. column2: Rochelle
column3: Rochelle. There are so many French films that could be described as "a young girl's strange erotic journey from Milan to Minsk" - the sexual activities/awakenings of pretty young teenagers is somewhat of a national obsession. It's hard to pick just one.  Maurice Pialat is widely known as "the French Cassavetes" (or
column4: if you are British
column5: "the French Ken Loach") which is the shorthand way of saying he's French
column6: made films on the fringe of the European studio system
column7: imbued his pictures with unsentimental realism
column8: and is well-liked by film snobs who see Pialat's lack of relative mainstream success on these shores as proof of their sophisticated taste. His feature length debut
column9: L'Enfance Nue
column10: was tendered the Francois Truffaut mark of approval (it was produced by the master) as well as a Prix Jean Figo. That award is given each year to a promising French director
column11: generally a young one though Pialat was a forty-four when he got his. He cemented his reputation as un auteur with 1987's Sous le soleil de Satan
column12: which not only won him the Palme d'Or but iconoclast status for life when he flipped off some booing audience members while accepting it. Sounds like a guy I could like.  If only A Nos Amours were a better film.  The picture stars sixteen-year-old Sandrine Bonnaire as the frequently-nude (not as titillating as it sounds) Suzanne
column13: a confused French teenager wandering from one hollow sexual encounter to the next. She says she's only happy when she's in the arms of one of her paramours and we don't blame her: Suzanne's home-life is at best unusual
column14: at worst fairly grotesque. Dad (played by Pialat himself) flies the coop early on
column15: leaving his son
column16: pudgy tyrant Robert (Dominique Besnehard) in charge of both daughter and half-crazy Mom (Evelyne Ker). Emotional and physical abuse relents only for short passages of awkward conversation
column17: often hinging on some sort of inappropriately sexual subject that tinges everything in something akin to unconsummated incest. Mom calls daughter a slut who trades sex advice with Dad while fielding interminable compliments about her body from her brother who himself has become a surrogate husband to Mom. Everyone in this family (Suzanne included) seeks to make life miserable for everyone else
column18: and in their own creepy ways they succeed.  Plenty of women seek the affections of too many men (or too many of the wrong men) to compensate for an absent father - such are the incontrovertible facts that clich is made of. It's the sort of unsophisticated platitude-masquerading-as-wisdom we've come to expect from daytime talk shows
column19: peddled to prostitutes and cheating spouses. In his own quasi-verit manner
column20: I imagine Pialat was seeking to subvert the clich
column21: deconstruct it
column22: transcend it - rarely does it actually come off. The meandering quarrels
column23: beatings
column24: and post-coital chit-chats all have the feel of work-shopping actors being put through an exercise rather than real life
column25: even the life of a sexually-obsessed French person. Pialat never truly gets under the surface of these characters
column26: frquently mistaking the bizarre and cruel for honest characterization (it's no surprise Catherine Breillat is such a fan of a the picture). One hundred minutes pass
column27: and yet we still feel as though we do not know these characters - they remain only our acquaintances
column28: obnoxious ones at that
column29: and if it's all the same we rather wish we hadn't been introduced.  Interesting footnote: One of Suzanne's first sexual conquests is an American tourist - we meet him as his has an argument with some French sailors
column30: whom he calls warmongers. This is probably the only time in cinema you will see an American character call a French one a warmonger

 After completing my first year of law school, I really wonder why so many professors use this textbook.  More than half the people I spoke with in my class thought the casebook's usability was poor or worse.   Property is not a difficult class, aside from future estates and related issues (Rule Against Perpetuities).  The hardest thing about property is knowing the jurisdictional views on various aspects of property law, and this casebook does only an OK job highlighting that.  It is basically a lot of memorization and the learning of that material could have been substantially aided by organizing the book differently.  Additionally, many of its cases are not sufficiently edited, thereby necessitating that one read through too much irrelevant information to get to the legal issue.  My other case books are much more balanced on this issue.    As a last note, the production quality is lower than what I would expect for its price.  The paper chosen and the fair reproduction of what photos exist in the book contrast strongly with its price.    I suppose this sounds like a laundry list of complaints, but the book compares poorly to my other casebooks, simply stated

column1: G.P. Taylor struck out with his much-hyped debut
column2: the tepid religious fantasy "Shadowmancer." And the follow-up
column3: "Wormwood
column4: is even less engaging than Shadowmancer" was -- while it's fairly well written
column5: it's loosely strung together with dull characters and a plodding plot.    In the mid 1700s
column6: London is gripped by panic -- somehow the earth is overspinning
column7: and then it stops so that London is plunged into permanent night. A young servant girl
column8: Agetta
column9: is terrified of what is going to happen
column10: especially because her master
column11: Kabbalah master and scientist Dr Sabian Blake
column12: is predicting that a comet called Wormwood will strike the earth.     This information comes from the mysterious book
column13: Nemorensis
column14: that Blake was given by a stranger. The Nemorensis supposedly contains all the secrets of the universe. Unfortunately
column15: the book also exerts a sinister influence over Agetta. But in an attic is Tegatus
column16: an angelic being who might just be the savior London needs...    Religious fantasy
column17: or fantasy with religious undertones
column18: is not a bad thing -- J.R.R. Tolkien
column19: C.S. Lewis and others allowed their religions to influence their life's work. But G.P. Taylor not only has the subtlety of a battering ram -- he's also quite boring. The story plods along in a string of little plot-related scenes
column20: without building up much momentum.    One of the biggest problems is the way Taylor handles the fantastical elements of his book. Okay
column21: there are weird creatures. Most fantasy books have those. But his seem to just be thrown into the mix for no apparent reason. His handling of superstition and science in the 1700s is sketchy at best
column22: no matter how brilliant a scientist Blake is meant to be.    Taylor has a decent enough writing style
column23: and he has a certain flair for description and atmosphere. But his style is also very repetitive and over-the-top -- where are the editors when you need them? What's worse
column24: his idea of creating a fantasy world seems to be to just toss in a few weird elements that have nothing to do with the plot. The actual fantasy plot is just more of Taylor's lukewarm
column25: generic Christian sentiments
column26: and some truly bizarre theology. Can angels drown?    The characters are as thin as the pages. There are a lot of characters for a relatively slim fantasy book
column27: and many of them are left underdeveloped. Blake and Agetta are the only ones who receive any character development
column28: and that isn't saying much. Agetta in particular seems almost manic
column29: considering how fast her moods swing. Tegatus the depressed angel is just freakin' boring.    G.P. Taylor strikes out again with "Wormwood
column30:
another dull religious fantasy that leaves a sour taste in the mouth. Boring, messy, and not worth the effort it takes to wade through

 If you're going to read one of the great classics of literature-and you should-don't pick up this edition.  It is a reprint of a version that dates back to the 1870s and was exposed more than 40 years ago for cutting nearly one-quarter of Verne's story and mistranslating much of the remainder.  Its reappearance in this edition is all the more amazing considering Tor's status as a leading science fiction publisher, and the company's willingness to perpetrate this fraud on is many readers is truly stunning.  If you want to truly get to know Verne's novel, pick up the elegant Naval Institute Press edition, in a modern, complete, updated translation, with commentary by the leading American Verne expert today, Walter James Miller.  That book also comes with many of the artistic engravings that illustrated the original French first edition (no illustrations are to be found in the B&N Mercier reprint).  Less attractive but more academic is the Oxford Classics version of Twenty Thousand Leagues.  This review is posted on behalf of the North American Jules Verne Society by Jean-Michel Margot, president NAJVS 
 This book was required reading for a class I took on Russian Art and Architecture, and I assure you that if it wasn't required I would not have wasted my time.  I never write reviews for anything, but this one was so bad, I couldn't help myself. I could not make sense of it at all, it rambled on and on, never getting to the point, never picking a path, never building on a theme. It bored me with it's vague attempts to build a song. I listened to it 2 times just to make sure I wasn't imagining how bad it was, and then I dumped it. It was not my style, and I don't see how it could be anybody's style, but that's just me. I felt obligated to voice my opinion and possible save somebody out there from being bitterly disappointed. Good Luck on your listing adventures
